entry.title: Dyfi Enduro 2014
entry.summary:
This weekend marked the annual Dyfi Enduro ride, this year a choice was given to ride 45km or 55km. I entered the 55km with the aim of getting to the bar at the bottom of dickos within around 4 hours.

Friday

Paul came over Thursday night and we headed to Eastridge to meet Andy so that I could show them round. We had a great ride and Andy had no trouble at all with the steep line, I managed to crash on it twice! We rode all the usual suspects although Paul ran most of it and freewheeled the descents as his rear mech hanger snapped just before the zig zag climb.

After riding, Paul and I continued on to aber to Dan's house where we'd be staying the night. We met up with Joe and Nick for some food in the glen before moving on to the ship and castle for more beer than was planned. Dan, the genius, had left some chicken cooking whilst we were out so we came back to a full meal of chicken with rice n peas. Top job!

Saturday

On Saturday we met Joe, Nick and a few others at Capel Dewi for a bit of a play about on some DH tracks. One side of the woods is quite lost to fallen trees but there are still plenty of tracks. I managed to badly case a double and hit my shoulder pretty hard but walked away from it so all good but a bit sore now. Joe hit the smallest (it ain't small) of the road gaps a couple of times and generally a good time was had by all. After riding Paul and I headed on to Mach and setup our tents etc... before being joined by Ben n Steph shortly after. Once Jase arrived we headed off to find food and wound up with dirty kebab shop pizzas, did the job though. We had a drink or two each in the beer tent before heading off to bed.

Sunday

The main event! Around 10.30 we headed to queue up for the start, already we were starting quite a way back and the start wasn't until 11! We had the rider briefing and off we went. I wanted to get to the top of the first climb as quickly as I could to avoid the bottleneck that always occurs at the first descent. That, I managed to do - along with Paul and Harris. Shortly after the first descent I lost them after I stopped for a wee. I was feeling quite good until I fell off on the second part of baileys. I was on some bedrock and both of my wheels disappeared as I tried to alter my line. Luckily I got away with no major damage but did bruise both of my hands which made for some painful descending the rest of the day. Jase passed me as I was having a break at the top of World Cup and I managed to catch him on the climb so we rode together up to the feed station. Cake, hi5 and nanas consumed it was quickly time to crack on again.

At this point we were riding with Paul and Harris again but once again they all quite quickly disappeared into the distance. I pushed the whole of the singletrack climb up to goshawk as my legs were hurting pretty badly but I got a pretty clear run down goshawk which was ace. At the bottom I hopped into a compression and BANG, tyre was flat instantly. I couldn't see any problems with the tyre so thought that it had somehow just burped majorly. Threw a tube in and off I went. Half way up the next climb I heard a hissing... Jumped off the bike and found that the tube was poking through a big hole in the tyre. Balls. I'd used my only tube so started walking, a very kind chap gave me a tube so I set to work with my toothpaste tube tyre boot but, alas, it wasn't big enough for the hole. Another very generous person came to my rescue and gave me a Park Tool tyre boot. I managed to get it all fitted (took a few goes as even that boot wasn't quite big enough) and wahey I was off again. I was quite fresh by this point having rested for over 30 minutes fixing the tyre so stormed up to dickos. I decided that it probably wasn't a great plan to ride dickos so tried to skirt round on a fireroad. Just after I passed the first crossing on dickos the fireroad went uphill again and I was not having that so cracked on down dickos itself. Just past the photographer and about 10 metres from the end of the track I crashed again, scraping my right hand side down some rocks. That one hurt a bit but all the damage was superficial so I picked myself back up and got myself over to the bar at the bottom for a small beer.

At this point I decided that the long route probably wasn't wise with a big hole in my tyre so headed to the finish. Luckily, Paul had only just finished the long loop so we headed back together. About half way back my bike started to get a bit bouncy, another tube down. Paul had a large boot in the form of part of a milk carton so we fitted that and a new tube. That got me back to mach no worries where we got our mugs and caught up with everyone else to see how they got on.

After showers we wandered over the road to where there was a smaller beer tent and a couple of food vendors. We first went for mexican from the Green Goat. Jolly good it was too, this beer tent was empty so we also managed to use some sofas which was somewhat nice!

We then chose to sample the burger stand, I had falafel. This was also a win, after another drink we headed back to Dyfi HQ where we drank some more and caught up with old faces. There was also some entertainment in the form of a fire ring with people riding through it.

A cracking weekend despite the actual dyfi ride not going my way. Big respect to Paul for riding it singlespeed when he isn't used to it. Big thanks to the organisers and all of the marshalls and people lining the course in various places too. I managed somewhere around 4h30 for the 45km loop so if I hadn't had problems with my tyre then I'm confident I would have made the bar by 4 hours.

entry.title: Red Kite Events Gravity Enduro 1
entry.summary:
This weekend was the Red Kite Events gravity enduro 1 at Llanwrtyd Wells. This gravity enduro differed from others that I've seen in that there were no strict stage start times. On Saturday stages were open 2pm-5pm and Sunday 10am - 5pm. This meant that after finishing a stage you could wait for your mate(s) and then pedal on to the next stage in your own time (within reason).

Saturday

Saturday was just 2 stages with practise in the morning. The stages opened at 2pm so I picked Rich up at around 9 and we got to Llanwrtyd Wells at about 11.30. We picked up our race plates and decided to crack to get in a practise loop before the stages opened.

Stage 2

We practised stage 1 and then moved onto stage 2, which was quite a long way away but the majority of the climb was on a long, shallow fireroad. As we reached the bottom of stage 2 we met the organisers setting up the timing gate and they told us that we could do stage 2 timed before stage 1, saving us pedalling back to 1 and then back to 2 again. Stage 2 was exposed with a short, slippery, rooty section at the top followed by a mixture of flatout loose rocky descents and flat pedally sections all linked with sharp, open hairpins. Finishing with a grassy section into a hairpin and a sprint to the finish. It was good fun and pretty difficult to ride the hairpins fast. My timed run went pretty well with no major issues but did stall out and have to scoot the bike on the very last corner as it had an awkward hole toward the exit. Got down in 00:02:52 which put me at 19/25 for the stage.

Stage 1

The climb up to stage 1 was a long burner of a fireroad, not too steep but with a pretty viscious headwind for our practise run. Stage 1 itself was fast singletrack with loose rock, plenty of ruts and a steep bedrock section. It was a fun descent although a bit too flat out for my tastes with a bit of a very short, sharp climb toward the end. In my timed run I hit a realy slow line at the top that had me hitting a large grass tuft and nearly coming to a stop. I also managed to get stuck in a rut that I didn't want to be in and crashed trying to get out of it. That left me turning into the bedrock chute a bit too sharp and hitting another big grass tuft, I stayed on the bike but it all got a bit wild. Other than that the run went pretty alright! Got down in 00:03:04 which put me at 18/25 for the stage.

All in all we managed about 34km, quite glad we managed to cut out about 15km by not having to go back to stage 1. After the stages we headed back to race HQ where Neil (the race organiser) provided us with a beer each and we had a good chat before another beer and then getting changed. I managed to pick a shower that didn't go hot at all - a cold shower after a cold, wet ride (did I mention that I also fell off in a river?) was not the one! There aren't many showers in my life that I would describe as emotional but that was one of them. After getting ready Rich n I headed to the pub for a couple of drinks before heading to the pasta party! As part of the event we had a free pasta meal at the Drovers Rest. I opted for the spag bol and good it was too. The results for the day also appeared, I was coming in at 18th with a time of 05:56:28 (bear in mind that 4 of the 25 riders weren't riding Saturday so just got a flat 5 minutes for each stage). Rich was in 13th with 05:03:78. That result was good enough for me! A couple of beers and it was time for bed. Camping in the rain, joy.

Sunday

Up at around 8 and ready to go by 9.15, we were the first people to head out. We got to the top of stage 1 at about 10.05 and cracked on.

Stage 1

This went much better this time, despite being much more slippery from the rain. I hit the same crap line at the top as I totally forgot about but managed to keep it together for the entire run. It felt slower than Saturday but I didn't crash and hit better lines so hoped for a better time. Turned out that I got 00:03:08 so slower despite not crashing! This time got me 21st for the stage and still 18th overall. Rich must have had a bit of a problem as he came in slower than me and lost a couple of places to 16th.

Stage 2

This run also felt slower than Saturday but I gave what I could in the sprints and managed to hit a better line around the bottom corner which cut off the actual corner. I had no idea how to stack this one up time wise. At the bottom of this stage we bumped into a fella called Chris who had an identical net time as Rich for Saturday. We continued to ride with him until stage 4. He's into his XC racing and seemed to be pretty rapid. This stage I managed 20th in 00:03:06, another time slower than Saturday. This dropped me down to 19th overall. Rich managed to claw back to 15th after this one.

Stage 3

This stage was ridden blind and was a good old pedal from stage 2 but after pedalling back up to the top of stage 2 it stayed on the top of the hill which was pretty nice. There was a short, rocky non-stage descent too :). Stage 3 could be described only as utterly flatout. The surface was man made and ridiculously fast, mostly quite wide and straight with a couple of corners and hairpins. It went on for quite a while and as I was starting to feel a bit tired a climb appeared. This was bad news. I dropped several gears and sprinted as well as I could (not very well) before it dropped into descent again. The finish was quite steep with a couple of big corners before the finish line. It was good but really, really tiring! At this point we found out that one of the timing wands had broken and that we'd have to wait for all riders to come through stage 3 before we could ride stage 4, luckily there was a cafe nearby serving hot food so we chilled out there for a while (we were the first people to reach the bottom of stage 3) before pedalling up to stage 4. I came in at 00:04:40 in 22nd for the stage keeping me in 19th overall. Rich had gained another place to 14.

Stage 4

Another blind stage. A couple of minutes after we got to stage 4 Neil turned up with the person doing the timing for the stage and told us to ride the top of stage 4 and loop back round as they'd be a few minutes. This gave us a quick taste of what was to come. The top section was singletrack, wooded, really rooty and really slippery. I was happy! After we looped back round to the top we got ready to go. I was going to be first off, there was a bit more of a delay and almost everyone was around before I went, including a few who had wandered down into the woods. Bit of pressure! But having people cheering in the woods felt good and I kept it together. After doing the top section the track got a bit more difficult, less roots but a bit steeper with some steep, sharp corners. This section dropped onto the fireroad in a pretty horrific rut before going really steep with a few steep, sharp corners. Unfortunately I came unclipped and rode at the finish line with 1 foot on the pedal, no problem BUT there was a bridge just before the finish and I missed it. This meant that I had to get off and run to the bridge and on to the finish. This was definitely my favourite stage! The track continued downhill to the cafe after the finish and that bit was pretty good fun too. This was my best stage (relative) to others despite losing a bit of time at the end, I came in 1s behind Rich at 00:02:09 which was 15th for the stage. Despite this I dropped a place overall to 20th.

Stage 5

To get to stage 5 was back the way we came from stage 2 (stage 5 and 2 were the same track). Starting with a steepish, longish climb back to the top of the hill. We made our way back until the route diverted off from the way that we came. Everything suddenly went very Dyfi. The track was quite undulating and all bedrock with some massive, deep puddles. It was quite fun but I wouldn't have minded not doing it by that point! We eventually made our way to the top of the stage and cracked on. I believe the phrase is "had a mare". On the top rooty bit I managed to somehow come off. On the next section which was fast and loose into a hairpin I managed to just not be able to stop and overshot the corner. Further down I crashed again! Remounted to find my bars were pointing nowhere near where the wheel was so had to dismount and pull them a bit straighter. I was also pretty shot for the sprints but gave what I had. Definitely my worst run of the day but despite the crashes still finished in one piece which is a win in my books! As expected my time for this one wasn't good, 00:04:05. A minute slower than my run down stage 2 earlier in the day, and 23rd for the stage.

Sunday turned out to be around 48km so a good size ride. We got back, cleaned bikes, selves and got changed. Had a cup of tea (beer for Rich) and then headed off with a couple of freebies - mucoff silicon spray and an ID system that attaches to your helmet. Despite the weather being horrible for pretty much the whole weekend it was a cracking event. I really enjoyed the format, being about to chill out a bit and ride the transitions with Rich. The event was quite small which meant that you recognised pretty much everyone when you saw them and made for a nice vibe. Overall I came 21st out of 25 with a clear indicator that to do better I need to be braver on the fast descents. Rich finished in 13th a couple of minutes up on me. Overall, I learnt some of the area and didn't muller myself so I'm a happy bunny. Bring on rounds 2 and 3, which apparently will have more stages like 4, woohoo!

entry.title: Playing in the Dyfi
entry.summary:
The Dyfi forest is always a highlight to any of my weeks or weekends. The riding is top notch. I designed a route that took in every (very nearly anyway) descent that I knew on the Corris side of the forest, including a bonus descent that I didn't know. We started off parking just below the climachx car park (it was closed) and span our way up toward Elephant. On the way up I spied footpath which I had thought had been logged so I decided that we'd throw this in as a bonus too.

The last time that I did footpath was quite a long time ago now, it was a pretty wide, quite muddy descent. Pretty average steepness for the dyfi. It's now a narrow, rocky descent but none-the-less still rather good. It is a bit of a short one though. Next, spin back up to Elephant!

Always a classic, starts out with a fairly long flat out as you dare blast down a rut before hitting a big bermed corner after which the trails unruts a bit and gets a bit rougher with a few small drops. We skipped the new Gravity Enduro but that they recently dug and popped out of the fireroad. We span along to the new bottom of Elephant (built for the enduro). This bit of trail is really, really awesome. They've added a descent that the dyfi really needed IMO. It's almost all dirt, unlike all of the descents which are very rocky. After the enduro the descent is now very rutty but that makes it a bit like riding on rails! I had to dab once going round a corner where my tyre scraped the inside of the rut but managed to clean the rest including the pretty steep and slick bottom section.

Next it was back up to the top of this bit to tackle Builth which was riding the same as it has done for years. Fast, rocky and pretty wild!

We span on up to the top of Dicko's which, again, is a Dyfi classic. With a mixture of rocks, mud and (since the gravity enduro) a bit of loam. As always, it was errr fast, rocky and pretty wild. Back up the climb past Builth and on Rocky Horror 1. I'd only done this once before and last time it was overgrown with brambles so I was prepared to have to do some clearing, only had to clear 1 bramble! The rest of the run was clean. It's steep and very, very rocky down this one. A few interesting bits where line choice matters quite a bit but yet another cracking descent.

Back up the climb past builth yet again and we did the short Dyfi Warm Up enduro descent. It's a bit of fun, not too steep but rocky with wheel grabbing holes if you pick your line wrong. We span back up past builth again (for the last time!) and cracked on to Nemesis. We found it quite a way up a technical singletrack climb. I hadn't done this before. Wow! It's great. It started out a bit twisty and very steep before developing out in a bit more of a flatout and then getting steep and tight again. Mixture of rocks and mud this time, mostly rocks! It dropped us out onto a fireroad a bit in the middle of nowhere so it was a bit of a trek back up to Tony. Despite this, Nemesis is getting added to permanent list of Dyfi trails that need riding.

We finished up on Tony the Tiger, the climachx final descent. Once again very rocky but also very long. Starts out in the woods and then opens up to where they've been logging before dropping back into the trees traversing back and forth along the hill before a load of tight(ish) switchbacks leading to the bottom. A nice way to finish out a ride!

Man, I love the Dyfi.

entry.title: Marin & Penmachno
entry.summary:
Before starting the guts of this post I just want to mention that after previous riding this week my body was pretty sore and aching so that may bias my opinions on these trails. Pedalling downhill pretty much just wasn't an option either. Going to be utterly ruined by Sunday - got Hopton, Dyfi and Eastridge to ride yet!

Marin trail

I met Harris at the Marin car park at about 11.15, the reason we didn't go up together was that he went via coed-y-brenin carpark to try find the rear maxle he lost on Sunday. He did indeed find it, huzzah! I'd done the Marin a few times before but not for a long time. Despite what a lot of people say on the internet I remembered really enjoying the Marin and it being one of my favourite trail centres.

Despite starting out with a singletrack climb, most of the Marin climbs are just nice fireroad spins. I know that some people seem to dislike climbing on fireroads but to me it's the best way to do it, spin away and conserve that energy for descending. Even on the first climb I could feel that my legs were still recovering from the coedy enduro, a bit sore and hollow feeling.

For the most part singletrack on the Marin trail is descending and good descending at that. There are some cracking descents there, the final one (Ride Fast Ride Free) being really quite excellent - and pretty long to boot. Another couple of descents that I can actually remember (so must have been of note) were "Pigs might fly" and "Dragon's Tail".

It took us 2 hours to do the 23km at a casual, sore pace so it'd be doable for us in well under that. It's a cracking bit of trail and is staying there as one of my favourite trail centres.

Penmachno trail

After the Marin we headed down to Penmachno unsure whether we'd do just one or both loops. By this point it had started to try to rain a bit but was generally still decent weather. We started out on a fireroad climb, rounded a corner and WHOOSH very gusty wind right into our faces, luckily this wind seemed to disappear at this 50m section! This trail has a lot of singletrack, it also has its share of fireroad but the ratio of ST:fireroad was higher than most trail centres that I've ridden. Unfornately, a lot of that singletrack is uphill or flat and the entire thing is very rough. Harris was having a hard time of it on a hardtail.

Before the split for loop 1 or loop 2 (does an extra loop + loop 1) we had done 1 descent, and it was mediocre at that. This led us to a decision that we'd only do loop 1 as this sort of trail just isn't our cup of tea. Luckily, it got better. Something worth mentioning is that this trail has a lot of fantastic views which at least redeems some of the horrible climbing. There were 1 or 2 more decent descents before the final 2. The final 2 descents were good, the final 1 being really good. Rocky, fairly challenging and fast. Oh, no need to pedal to feel fast either, just pumping - that's always high on my list of desireable things from a descent. They were fast enough to pretty exciting (especially if you didn't hit your line right) but also technical enough to be fun and a bit challenging. I love the feeling of barrelling along on trails that have a bit of something about them, really good feeling that is. The last 2 were what I've come to expect from Wales - they were very wet and very rocky with some steepish bits.

I think that I'd go back and do either of them but I'd take the Marin over Penmachno. If you go and only have time to do one then don't do either! Instead, just do the final descents of both :)

entry.title: Pelican Github Autopublish
entry.summary:
This isn't strictly development but could be handy for someone.

This blog uses a piece of software called Pelican, if you hadn't guessed. Pelican is a static blog generator, this means that it takes a theme (some HTMl like templates and some css), blog posts (mine are written in markdown) and some settings and it creates a static html output ready to be hosted somewhere.

For the hosting I use Github pages, mostly because I already use github and it means that hosting is free. I'm a huge fan of free. These two marry together quite nicely.

To do the publish I use ghp-import and just push to my gh-pages branch. The pelican docs actually describe how to set this up. I use the post-commit hook approach and it's brilliant. BUT I don't want to have to run this stuff everytime, I have to ssh into my server and then do a git add and commit. This is where my autopublish process comes in.

The first step that I did was to move my blog post folder to dropbox and create a link within my blog folder to that. This means I can write posts anywhere so long as I can upload to dropbox and it'll be visible to pelican to do it's magic.

The next step I thought I would do is just to add some form of watcher for git so that when content in the source folder changes it'd add and commit and hey presto the hook would do the rest. Git doesn't follow links. That's that one dead then. However, Pelican has a --autoreload option so that you can leave it running and it'll auto regenerate the output whenever it detects a change, OK so I'll use that. Next I changed my post-commit hook so that it'd only run ghp-import and do the push to gh-pages, not create the content. I downloaded Gitwatch and ran it to look at my blog folder (not the source folder, the whole thing). Final step, I setup ssh-agent so that I wouldn't have to supply password each time git tried to do a push.

This means that I now stick a file in my github folder, pelican picks that up and regenerates the output, gitwatch picks up the new output and does an add and a commit firing the post-commit hook. The hook runs ghp-import and pushes to gh-pages. Hey presto, my new post is on my blog!

entry.title: Tipping chicks
entry.summary:
My Dad owns a chicken farm where he takes chicks from a couple of days old and grows them until they're about ready to start laying eggs. At the point where they're old enough to lay they get taken off to another farm and he then gets a new batch of chicks. As I'm currently on holiday and on the farm I got roped into "tipping chicks" today.

The process is basically that chicks arrive in stacked plastic baskets on trolleys in a lorry. The trolleys are rolled into the shed and we then put the baskets out on feed on the shed floor. Once this done someone sprays the chicks with a vaccine and we wait for them to dry. Once that's done we (gently!) tip them out onto the feed, stack up the empty baskets and roll the baskets out to be reloaded back on to the lorry. Simple!

Not so great when your body is aching from riding and the temperature in the shed is 27C though...

entry.title: Coed-y-brenin 2013
entry.summary:
This weekend marked the annual Coed-y-brenin Enduro, a 60km mountain bike endurance event. Last year Ben and I did it, it took us 8.5 hours (according to my gps) and we were nearly dead last. Felt utterly destroyed at the end and swore to never do it again. Somehow, we wound up doing it again.

Saturday

I've been talking about Myherin to the others for a while now so put a plan in action to get it done. We met Dave Reed and Pete in the arches car park and set about waiting for Ben and Rich to turn up. Which they did, 40 minutes late! Unfortunately, I wasn't feeling great so the descents were a bit hairy and the climbs just hurt. I cut the loop a bit short with Dave, we just skipped Blaen Myherin whilst the others went off that way. We cut off at the steep climb and just headed back via Brashy Dive. I then met the others in Aberystwyth. I think that they enjoyed the ride!

After grabbing some food for the evening we headed off up to our log cabin near Coed-y-brenin. It was pretty snug but had everything we needed and was really comfy. At this point we also met up with 2 of Ben's mates who we were sharing the cabin with, Conrad and Nath. We cooked a big ole pasta bake and then watched utterly dire films until bed time.

Sunday

Starting out how all big bike days do - porridge and a cuppa tea. We packed up all of our stuff and headed off to coedy to sign up and get riding. The sign on had moved this year down to the newly kitted out visitors centre, although we didn't go inside to have a look. By the time we got there and signed on, met up with Jase etc... it was about time to go join the starting queue. We opted to queue about 3/4 of the way back as we had no plans to go racing. The first few km were slow and a tad stop/start until the pack thinned out. The first descent (cane & abel) was a fair queue although completely cleared by the time we hit the actual descent. This may have been because we pointed out a path near the descents and joked we should go ride that. A lot of the people around us decided that, in fact, that was exactly what they were going to do.

The ride had some great descents and a few tough climbs mixing up both fire track and singletrack. Of note were the steep, slippery, rad descent down to the river (not trail centre) although I did hit a tree causing our mini-train to stop and then hit my pedal on a rock just before a chute causing another stop, although still managed to ride them out. Sorry guys! Rocky horror near the end was also a good bit of trail although by that point my body felt like I'd been in a fight.

It was an awesome weekend full of good riding. Will probably do the coedy again next year too, didn't feel nearly as bad this year - although didn't feel that ride during the ride. Thanks to all the Summit crew who made it happen as well as the people manning the feed station and the emergency services crew(s?), and everyone else involved!

I may expand this write-up as the week goes on!

entry.title: Weekend at Rich's
entry.summary:
On Friday we leave for Scotland so some of us have been scrabbling to get a last bit of riding prep in before Bean utterly destroys our legs. Harris, Rich and I decided that we wanted to get a long ride in this weekend. As Rich lives near good riding and now has his own house we decided to go ride there and stay for the weekend. Unfortunately, Harris had been ill for a lot of last week and I got the text on Friday afternoon saying that he wasn't going to make it.

Saturday morning Maura and myself set off for Rich's place, which is only about an away. We arrived at about lunch, chilled out for a bit and then Rich and I decided we'd better go ride in the Lickey's. The aim was for a decent sized ride but with the longer ride being Sunday. Gotta say I thought that the Lickey's were pretty awesome, not a lot of elevation but loads of stuff to ride and a lot of it pretty steep. Even some small drops and the like. There's plenty of potential there for a bit of cheeky building away from the beaten path too.

View over Birmingham from above the golf course

As soon as we hit the first climb I could feel something was amiss, my legs were still aching from Harris destroying them the Saturday before! Whilst I could happily spin away I felt like I had no actual strength in them and that they were hollow. Luckily, most of the climbs were steep but not too steep so I could spin them in 1st gear. We did about 26km and it took us 2 hours although a reasonable chunk was on the road to and from the woods. I'm keen to get back there and explore some more. The SLX brakes proved themselves to be a worth investment impressing me all the while. The rubber queens were also good, less draggy as the high rollers but just as grippy - think I'll be using the larsens for most of my riding over Summer though.

Second hand RQ, plenty of life - bargain!

In the evening we went for a curry which was pretty nice and then a couple of pubs. We wound up in a pub near to Rich's house that had a live band which was a pretty awesome end to the day.

Sunday, we had arrange to meet another Ben (Bish) at the Wyre at 11. Weeeell, that didn't happen - Rich and I set off at 11 so we told them to just ride on and we'd bump into them somewhere. We actually wound up arriving at the Wyre at 11.40. The Wyre was really dry and the descents there are pretty much all fast, flat out. Whilst that isn't majorly my cup of tea (I prefer more techy stuff) it was awesome fun. There are a couple of pretty techy, steep descents that kept the bag varied and the climbs are steep but fairly short. My legs felt much better for this ride and Rich was aching from the previous ride so we had a pretty nice pace. I previously hadn't enjoyed riding the Wyre but it's certainly on my list of things worth riding now. In the end we did about 30km in about 2.5 hours (runkeeper managed to lose gps signal so not really sure!).

A lovely day

Lots of dry singletrack!

Brief brake for ice creams

My bike doesn't fit Rich's rack with the shock on

We got back and chilled out for a bit before playing the bike fettling game. I bled my rear brake to try get it as good as the front, I was not successful in that although it feels no worse than before. Rich decided to try track down the horrible creak/cracking sound under load on his bike. We took his freehub off and it was pretty obvious, the bearings quite literally fell out of the body in a number of pieces. So he's got some work to do before Scotland! Rich then cooked a great chilli and after eating Maura and I returned to Oxford.

A great weekend and hopefully many more to come in Rich's new place.

entry.title: Prospect Big Bike Ride
entry.summary:
The Dyfi Enduro is now a week away today it's been ages since I last did a real big ride. Therefore, I set out to plan a ride for this weekend and came across the Prospect Hospice Big Bike Ride by chance, a 50km ride over Swindon way. Ben came over on Saturday so we did a quick 25km ride round Boars Hill and also had a bit of a play on the Dean Court dirt jumps - they're better than I been expecting. Good news!

On Sunday we headed over to Swindon and signed on for the 50km loop, turns out that we had about 25 minutes to spare before the event started so had loads of time! The start was staggered into small groups but we didn't have to wait long. The first few km were on the croft trail which, from what we rode, seemed like pretty good fun. It was long until we (us and the guy in front of us) caught up to the group in front and had to go a bit slower but pretty soon we were on double track off the trail so could ride at our own pace.

Most of the ride was on double track with a few single track descents (and one climb) and a bit of road. We were pretty surprised by how hilly it was. There was even one road climb where, whilst we were going up it, I was the only person who stayed on the bike! It was really good fun and a nice day on the bikes. We were pushing quite hard to try to treat it as a bit of training for next weekend and it fit the bill pretty well! Unfortunately I did have a crash, about 100m from the finish line. There were two trees that we had to ride through and I found out the hard way that my bars didn't fit, oh well - no harm done :). Bring on the dyfi!

entry.title: JQuery Hackday
entry.summary:
Yesterday marked the Jquery UK conference which was hosted by White October in Oxford. Unfortunately I didn't go to the conference but today they also hosted a hackday along with JS Oxford which I did make it to! The idea for the hackday was to have remote control cars that we could control from our laptops, phones etc... but also control using javascript run under nodejs.

The car!

I arrived at about 8.45 and by 9 was sat on a table with 2 others and starting to hack. I'd already managed to install something called libkoki which we used for some machine vision stuff but unfortunately had the wrong version of node installed to build the node bindings for it that the White October guys had written for us. 2 versions of node later and I had it working along with being able to run code on the car, pretty exciting stuff!

I was on a team with 3 others - Sunil, Phil and Toby. We were using the Blackberry sponsored car for the day. There were no real restrictions on what we could do with the day and with the cars although there was mention of a race at the end of the day. As we all had the koki stuff working we decided that we'd try to navigate around the race track using that, going from marker to marker. Libkoki is a library used in student robotics competitions. The idea behind it is that there are a number of markers that the library can detect and extract some static and some dynamic information from using a live camera feed. The markers provide information such as which number in a series it is as well as distance from the camera, rotation etc....

One of the koki markers

The track

The koki markers on the inside of the track were even numbered ones and on the outside odd. We decided to use a pretty simple approach of just turning anti-clockwise when we detected and got close to an even marker, and the opposite with an odd marker. I had tried to write a bit of logic to avoid hitting walls by using the angle of the car to the marker to work out the distance to the wall that the marker was on. I have a feeling that the value that I was using from the marker information wasn't actually the angle that I thought it was and this approach was never going to work if we didn't have a marker in sight anyway!

Now, in my masters I did quite a lot of work navigating a maze with a rover but for that I used sonar. Whilst the sonar that I used back then was quite noisy it was still remarkably easier than using a live camera feed! If your vehicle is sat in front of a wall that's 20cm away then that's pretty easy to tell with sonar, not so much with a camera. Whilst we did have koki at our disposal that only worked if a marker was in sight, which 20cm from a wall quite often is not the case. I was pretty shocked by just how hard dealing with no extra information such as that given by sonar was, certainly made it interesting.

Anyway, over the day our approach slowly developed (and our car hit many, many walls - they were only made from cardboard, luckily) and by the end we were bouncing between markers and working round the track relatively well, I think that we even managed half the track at one point. By the end of the day there was only one other team left and they had used an approach of edge detection on the tops of the walls. Their car was quite good at navigating some bits but not so good at other sections. In the end there was a race but the cars were controlled by people on phones instead!

Ready to race

The race is on

That dent in the wall wasn't there before...

The chicane

It was an excellent day and I had a lot of fun. If they ever put on another then I'll definitely try to be there. Big thanks to the guys who set it all up so that we could do what we did.

Can't go wrong with free beer

entry.title: Pro Ride Guides Airtime Course
entry.summary:
A while back Ben and I decided that a skills course could be a good idea. He found a jumps and drops course at Forest of Dean that is run by Pro Ride Guides. We found a date and sent the info on the others, it ended up being Ben, Taylor and myself booked onto the course. Today we did the course.

I got to the Forest of Dean at about 9.30 and Taylor n Ben showed up shortly afterward. Some faffing occured and we headed over to meet the 2 other guys and the coach - Dave, Chris and Al respectively. We had a brief chat and did some basic bike checks so that Al knew that we weren't riding death traps. We set out for a short spin on the blue route just to warm up a bit and get a fresh feeling of our bikes.

Once we'd done that we were at the top of a fireroad. Al explained how to correctly get into the attack position and how it should feel - he wanted us to be in that position with the rear brake covered for most of the day. Next he showed us how to correctly bring the bike into a manual (seems to be the key!) so we practised that for a while before progressing it into a bunny hop. An emphasis over the day was landing softly so we also had a go at that with the bunny hops. This part felt pretty good and already it was pretty clear I've got a nice collection of bad habits!

We then moved onto a small drop onto a fireroad to practise the technique for that. I was having some trouble with not pogo-ing upward at this point, something of a bad habit there as well. After that we pedalled up to the top of the hill and spent some time on a tabletop getting to grips with the jumping correctly part. This was also pretty difficult! We all started to get the hang of it though. Then it was time for lunch so we continued down the trail to the bottom trying practise pumping and jumping on our way down. He also told us to keep as light as possible on the bars so that front wheel can track better.

After lunch we returned to the small jumpy section where we had pactised the drops and setup on a jump that we could land on top of but had a distinct take off and landing. We put what we'd learnt into practise gradually adding more speed to try clear the jump. Ben managed to get the hang of it pretty quickly although he did almost attempt to superman off the front of the bike at one point. I was finding that I was getting the technique right more often by now and could tell when I had as it felt much better. Gradually adding speed it was all beginning to sink in. Once Al was happy that we were all capable of doing that he moved us onto a pretty small drop into a relatively steep slope. We spent some time putting into practise what we'd done earlier and everyone managed it with no problems what-so-ever. During these 2 sections it was also interesting to watch other people (not on the course) coming down and see how they were doing it wrong - with Al whincing almost every time in case they nailed themselves!

Once we'd got the hang of that drop we pedalled back to the top of the hill and played on a tabletop up there. At this point Al also showed us how to manual tables so we had a crack at that - Chris was pretty good at it and Taylor managed to get it really well on his last attempt. Ben and I weren't so great - more practise needed! We then did the descent we had done earlier trying to put into practise everything that we learnt but we said our goodbyes and headed off home.

I feel like I got a lot out of the course. Whilst I don't feel like I cracked it during the day it's given me the knowledge and theory that I needed so that I can come away and practise, practise, practise. Trying to practise jumps and drops around Oxford might be difficult but I can certainly practise the manuals and bunny hops - so I will be! Al was great - he was friendly, approachable and cracking jokes all day. He never seemed to get fed up of labouring the same points so that they hit home with us. A majorly key concept from the day seemed to be to relax!

entry.title: Boars Hill Ride
entry.summary:
Another lovely day today so I decided to go out on the MTB as planned. I was going to be riding alone so couldn't really be bothered with driving anywhere - that left me with Boars Hill. It was pretty bone dry and really fast. Not a very demanding route and a fair bit on road but a couple of short, steep climbs and one descent that's actually pretty good. It's just off the main path and is actually pretty technical and hard to go fast on. There are also some impressively massive houses up the top of boars hill and as I passed one there were 2 Ferrari's waiting to pull out.

Managed about 20km and took just over an hour, pretty fun little ride and ideal for after work! This was also the first ride in aaaages where I've taken no bag so no tools, no water etc... Felt quite nice not having the bag on my back!

entry.title: Aberystwyth Easter Trip
entry.summary:
Easter weekend we had decided to rent out a caravan and do the nant-mach-nant ride. There would be Ben, Rich, Jase, Pete, Rob and myself staying in the caravan and we'd do the ride with Dave and the ystwyth MTB crew. We also planned to do a bit of Clarach and maybe Myherin too.

Friday

Early start, packed the car and was en-route to Ben's at 6.20am. The drive was good and I turned up at 8.20, I had to wait 5 minutes for Ben to turn up but then we cracked on with the bike fettling. On my list of things were to do were: cut down steerer, check damper circuit for fluid, change brake pads, perform volume reduction mod on shock, bleed front brake and change chain ring. Not a huge list but these things always take time, surprisingly we had an hour to spare before Rich turned up at about 11.30. A bit of fettling on his bike and we were on our way to aber.

A bit of fettling with my bike!

Adding a shim to my shock for the volume reduction

The weather on the drive over to aber was sunny the whole way and aber itself no different. We checked in at Aberystwyth holiday village and headed over to the caravan to get changed and drop stuff off. The caravan was pretty big. Basic but everything we needed. We did everything that we needed and cracked on over to Clarach woods for some mini-DH.

The drive over to aber

The trails were dry and riding brilliantly. We spent a couple of hours there riding various tracks before heading back to the caravan. This was the first proper downhill stuff that I'd ridden on my full sus and it was taking a bit of getting used to but felt really good. We got back to the caravan park just after the other guys pulled in which worked out well.

The main living space in the caravan

Dry as a bone!

A few more:

© Copyright Rich Grundy

Saturday

Big ride day. We were going to do the nant to mach and back with the ystwyth mtb guys. We managed to get to Morrisons at about 9.15 to get some breakfast at the cafe and grab some riding food. The cafe food was somewhat less than average! We turned up to Pendam car park at about 10 to find Dave and Pete already there ready to go.

A bit of breakfast

A bit of faffing and we were off out away from nant on the conti loop. At this point I feel I should mention that the fresh brake pads meant that my front wheel wasn't spinning freely at all! Anyway, we got to Anglers Retreat in fairly good time but there was a bit of snow on the ground. Dave and Pete made the decision to try a different route out to the mach 3 as they expected too much snow on the other. We cracked on and were met with deep snow and icy conditions everywhere. Dave floated the idea that we maybe abandon the plan as it'd just be a slog and not much fun. In the end we came up with the idea to ride to the mach 3 and then back to nant on a slightly different route to make a bit of a loop.

A lovely day

Looking out over nant-y-moch resevoir

It begins...

The snow didn't improve, we spent quite a lot of time hiking the bikes through the snow with the odd bit of riding where the snow was conpact enough to allow it or the trail went downhill. I had a nice lie down/slide on my arse going round a corner and had thought I'd broken my lev but it turned out to be a bit of outer cabling had got stuck, phew! We got back to Anglers Retreat via scaletrix and most of the ride back to the conti loop was actually ride-able. We did the ace descent back down to the conti loop and returned to nant via sidewinder and hippity hop. At this point Dave and Pete headed off home but Ben was keen to go do a bit more riding. There was a general lack of motivation within the rest of the group though. I was shot but if everyone else wanted to keep going I was happy to do so on the conditions that I'd probably have to walk the worst bits of climbs. In the end we decided to call it a day.

There was plenty of this!

Represent

Jase getting it sideways

What, no snow?

Fantastic day out that, whilst it didn't go to plan, was still great fun and a bit of an adventure. Big thanks to Dave and Pete for guiding us!

In the evening we wound up in Lopburi Thai Restraunt for food and as always the food was top notch. I had a chicken panang curry made "as hot as you can". It was most excellent. We popped along to spoons for a pint to start the night out. After said pint we wound up going back to the caravan park due to everyone being knackered!

A few more photos:

© Copyright Rich Grundy

© Copyright Rich Grundy

Sunday

We had no plans for Sunday other than to just ride something. We had a bit of a slow morning getting up late and tidying the caravan/packing our stuff away. We wound up having a Spoons breakfast and we about ready to go ride at midday, destination: Clarach. Having seen how dry it was on Friday and we had such a good laugh we decided that we had to go back and to also show the other guys who hadn't been there before. We spent a good 4-5 hours in the woods and had a brilliant time. Rob, Ben and I did the big double which was a big thing for Ben as it managed to get in his head and he's spent about 3 years trying to get up to doing it. The trails were riding brilliant and were all really fast, was a brilliant way to spend the afternoon and I think that the only crash was mine too! Luckily I got out unscathed.

Classic stand and look at it

Ben overshooting it like a boss

© Copyright Rich Grundy

All in all a brilliant weekend of bikes and big thanks to everyone who made it what it was.

entry.title: Hat Tournament Creator
entry.summary:
I've been meaning to write something about this for a little while now and 2 days ago I received an email from a tournament organizer in the states so that's prompted me to do this. He'd found my code on github and wanted to know how to go about running it, well it just so happens that I actually have it hosted at http://www.hattournamentcreator.co.uk/ so I just pointed him at that. I got another email saying that it did what he wanted and that he'll pass the word on to other organizer. I'm pretty happy that it's helped out at least 2 people in the world now! If it's helping even a small number of people then it's worth it for me.

So, how it works. First, I'll explain the UI and then a little bit about the back end (at a high level). The site allows you to select manual or csv entry, along with an example csv to try to help people out a bit. Manual entry is frankly crazy as it'd take ages to add any reasonable number of players, I also haven't tested it as well as I've tested the csv stuff. Anyway, we've selected our csv file (which we already have as we have to keep a record of players anyway...) and we hit upload. The site then loads all that player data in a big grid. You can edit players in the grid to change names, metrics, etc... in case of any mistakes. The grid is pretty flexible and you can reorder the columns and set the sort order on any of them. You've got your players all setup so now we need to setup the metrics. This is the important bit, this is how the app will assign points to players. Each attribute that defines a players skill is given a multiplication factor. Stolen from the site itself: For example if I was doing this for Ultimate Frisbee then I'd maybe give Cutting a value of 2 and Handling a value of 2 then I'd hit generate formula. This'd give me (Cutting * 2) + (Handling * 2).

So Bob who has 3 cutting and 4 handling gets 14 points but Dave who has 1 and 2 respectively gets only 6. At this point we also need to define how many teams we want creating and whether or not to balance the genders so that all teams have the same number of girls and the same number of guys. We hit Generate teams, some magic occurs and we get a csv back that has all of our teams set up for us :). A little example - using the example csv on the website. This example has 4 skill attributes: cutting, handling, years since playing and years of experience. Years since playing is a negative skill as people get rusty as the years go by and they haven't played... so I'm going to give that a value of -1. It's not a hugely important attribute but I want it taken into consideration. I give years of experience 2, it's not that important - I mean you can have played for 10 years and be rubbish but experience does mean that you know how to react to given situations. Cutting and handling are the big guns, I'm going to give them 4 each as I feel that they're equally important as one another. The point generation formula that I get is:

(Handling * 4) + (Experience * 1) + (Cutting * 4) + (Years Since Playing * -1)

That looks fine to me. I'm going to have 6 teams in this tournament and I want to balance the genders too. I hit generate and get my teams back. The teams file also includes a few little extras like the average points per player for each team. In this example my averages per team are: 16.95, 17.9, 17.4, 18.35, 19.63 and 20.52. That's not a huge variance and should make the teams pretty even making for a fun tournament. I feel a bit sorry for Name 68 who has been assigned -4 points, that's gotta sting! As the player data for this example was literally random numbers (I wrote a script to generate it) I'd expect real world data to give closer points per team.

Onto how this thing actually works then. The grid is just jqgrid which, tbh, I don't recommend. When I get round to it I'll rewrite it to use datatables, although I haven't actually tried it yet so it could be rubbish! Jqgrid does all the work for the grid stuff so I won't cover that. The algorithm for the team creation is the meat so let's talk about that. In my opinion I've used a pretty naive approach and it's probably not the most optimal way to do it but it works, which is the important bit here. Just to mention, this site uses python and a load of javascript. The team creation stuff is all in python. My javascript skills are much strong but I like to keep dipping into python just to remember how it works! Anyway. First we deal with our metrics, we create a dictionary of the attributes that actually map to skills - just cast the value to a float and if it's 0 and doesn't throw an exception we class it as a skill! Next up is sorting out the gender stuff, just determining which gender format is used really.

Onto some of the fun stuff then, the next step is to iterate over every player and work out their points value before adding the player to the relevant gender array (we need to balance them remember). We quick sort each array so that the highest ranked players are nearest the "top" (index 0). The next step is to split the array(s) of players into equal sized lists (plus one for the players that don't fit into the equal lists). The reason for this will become clear now, this effectively means that we have several lists and each list contains similar skilled players. We now do the actual "teaming". We iterate over our new lists of players one by one. For each list we generate an index using a weighted random (the weight is linked to how many points the team has, the random is just to add a bit of variance) and then remove the player at that index and add them to the current selected team. We do this until we've run out of players and then we create and serve the file up.

It's quite hard to explain and the easiest way to see how the algorithm works is to just look at, it's kinda commented! You can find the code at https://github.com/chvck/Hat-Team-Generator and main.py and utils.py are the key files for this stuff. At this point I should probably actually mention why this app was created! A couple of years ago I played Ultimate Frisbee at Aberystwyth University and the club had its 15th year anniversary. To celebrate this they put on a hat tournament and I was approached to see if I could make something to create the teams so that the committee didn't have to do it manually. The result was this web app. Oh, the team I was on also won! No, I didn't fix it either!

entry.title: Scoopfree Litter Tray
entry.summary:
This is a bit off the beaten path of bike related things that I usually write about. This post is about a cat litter tray system called Scoopfree, it's one of those things that actually makes a difference. As the name suggests there's no scooping cat poo with this machine, you simply insert a cartridge and off you go until it's time to fit a new cartridge.

The way that this thing works is that it has a sensor (light beam I think) that when crossed triggers what I'd called an event. Once this event has occured then the litterbox counts down for 20 minutes (light blinks to let you know) and then it self-cleans. The self-clean process is simply a rake that runs down the tray and deposits the cat poo, dirty litter etc... in a compartment and then it runs back up. You'd think that this would smell pretty bad but it doesn't! They send a special form of litter that absorbs the smell, obviously it does start to get a bit stinky if you leave replacing the cartridge too long.

A cartidge lasts about a month for us with just Tesla to worry about and each one costs about a tenner from Vets UK. At the end of a work day when you're tired it's nice to come home and not have to muck about with cat poo. It's expensive for what it is but I do like having it around, especially as Tesla still insists on attacking it every time that it rakes! We've had it a few months now too.

entry.title: KS Lev seatpost
entry.summary:
I ordered one of those from Superstar yesterday and was pretty impressed when it turned up today. It feels like a nice piece of kit and is well finished. I also go free Haribo, yay! Anyway, on to the fitting, the instructions say to cut the outer into 2 pieces to enable you to fit a barrel adjuster, I chose not to bother and to see how it faired without it. Cutting the cables to size is slightly fiddly as the end piece has to be very exact and can't have cable sticking out. It took me a good while to get this bit right and get it fitted but wasn't too difficult. As a little bonus the lever can also act as a lock-on for an ODI compatible grip which is pretty cool.

The next step was the saddle, this is a lesson in why not to skip several pages of instructions as I wound up with my saddle pointing 90 degrees to where it should have been so I had to take it back off.

Turns out that the cradle for the saddle can be turned to various positions, bonus. To do this you have to take the head of the seatpost apart and unscrew the valve cap for the air - I took this opportunity to add a bit more air also. Once done I refitted the seatpost and wadda ya know, pointing in the correct direction.

It works well and feels smooth going through the travel. Thus far impressed - can't wait to take it on a ride.

entry.title: Nettlebed Ride
entry.summary:
Today I was due to head over to Christmas Common to do the route in Rough Ride Guide with Ben. Last night I got a handful of texts from him saying that he'd locked himself out of his room and then another this morning saying that he was still locked out and not going to make it. I suggested to George that we headed out for a ride in the afternoon and he agreed, I didn't fancy the full 40k of the Christmas Common ride so chose the 30k Nettlebed ride. The guide suggested that this route holds up pretty well in the wet so it sounded fairly ideal. We headed over at about lunch time.

We got there, got out of the car and it was bloody cold! We set off and pretty quickly picked up an offroad trail. The first half of the loop was pretty great, there we lots of fast descent although not too techy but with little bits to try jump off etc... It was also almost all off-road which was pretty nice. About 1/4 of the way in we bumped into a lady who flagged us down to help work out where we were. Turns out that she'd walked a lot further than she thought and kept saying that she always walks too far and doesn't realise how far she's gone! We helped her work out where she was and then continued on our way. At this point we did another fast descent that was also really quite long. This dropped us into Henley.

We rode through Henley and picked up a trail the other side, this is where it started getting really muddy. This bit of trail was a quick downhill followed by 2km of uphill, not very steep and should have been simple. But no, it was majorly churned up and muddy. In quite a few areas we just gave up and walked. We also stopped here for a spot of lunch next to this:

I checked the map and it seemed that the second half of the ride was to be uphill, it wasn't wrong. It was also pretty muddy most of the way. Although, we did go through a pretty flat wood that would be good fun in the dry. We managed to hit the last bit of road and go the wrong way, I misread the map so we wound up heading away from Nettlebed, not toward. Due to this and it starting to get a bit dark we skipped the last bit of offroad and just followed the road all the way back.

All in all a good ride, pretty good fun and should be pretty awesome in the dry! Since starting injecting meds I'm finding hills to be a major issue, there's just nothing in my legs. I'm hoping that I can just ride through it! We wound up doing 30km so not a bad effort. I'm also really enjoying the bike, it just feels great and really inspires me to want to have fun on it.

entry.title: Chilterns Night Ride
entry.summary:
I've recently got back in touch with a guy called Roger who I emailed when we first moved to Oxford about riding. He's part of a riding group who ride areas around Oxford, he passed me onto another guy called Ainsley. They had a ride planned for Tuesday riding in the Chilterns starting from Watlington, only downside being that they were starting at 6pm. It's about 18 miles away but involves going on the Oxford ring road - to be there for 6 that also meant going during rush hour. No matter I said that I'd be and started work early so that I could leave the house at about 5.15pm, I got a bit lose in Watlington trying to find the car park so got there about 6.05. Turned out that there were only 3 of us; Ainsley, Matt and myself.

We did introductions, setup bikes and headed out. To begin with we had a fairly long, decent gradient climb. This had me suffering, it takes me a good while to get warmed and this just wasn't the ideal way to do it! I had to take a couple of stops on the way up but wound up at the top, not too long a climb really. There weren't any really bad climbs on the ride, there were a few really muddy bits but not too many although the ground in places was quite draggy anyway. We did a couple of pretty cracking, fun descents. Nothing technical this time but i'm assured that there is plenty of steep, technical stuff in the area.

Toward the end of the ride there was a small set of steps that I managed to totally OTB down, I started without any run in and there was a bit of a depression before the wooden holdy bit in the step so I wound up doing my best superman impression. After that were a couple of steep little ladder things that were pretty good fun though. About a mile before the end my light just completely cut out with now warning which wasn't so good so I need to investigate if there's a loose connection or something. I think that I'll also buy a spare battery pack as they're so cheap.

All in all a really fun ride and I'm really glad that I got out there, hoping for more rides with these guys to come!

entry.title: Catching up
entry.summary:
Firstly I'll start off with the demise of my photo a day. Quite simple - I just don't do enough varying things in my day to day life. I found myself remembering that I hadn't taken a photo and having to hunt for something around the house. That wasn't the way that I had wanted to do it, I'd wanted to just take a photo of something significant each day and not had to think about taking the photo, just doing it. For that reason, I stopped.

Now let's talk bikes, surprise surprise. The Intense is pretty awesome and I'm very much enjoying riding it. I recently did a ride around Boars Hill which is local to me and has very little elevation. Despite being on a totally inappropriate bike it was still good fun and the Intense pedals much better and easier than I had expected. I've also changed my drivetrain and accidentally bought an 11-32 cassette, this hasn't been an issue yet either which surprised me a little. entry.title: Ben's Aber Weekend
entry.summary:

I'd never met Pete before but had been to the alps with Rab and Jase.

Anyway, once we'd sorted ourselves out we set out on a Summit + extras loop. The extras we threw in were White Fridge and a few did Reaper, I went off in hunt of another track that I've done before but wound up riding down a steep, rocky track until I bumped into Zorro and did the bottom half of that. Nant was, as always, a blast and I felt pretty good, although slow, on the climbs too. As a first I also took a hip flask on the ride, filled with port. Why had I never done that before?! After we got back and got the keys to our rooms in Maes y mor we showered etc... and set off to Lopburi for food. Lopburi was good as per usual, I had the jungle curry - tasty. After that we headed to spoons for coffeebucas. That was a bit of a warning sign that it was going to be a bit of a drunken night. We hit several pubs before venturing into pier pressure. That place has not improved although it has got stickier. I'm pretty sure that it hasn't changed since we were at uni, even the drinks are the same - just more expensive. At about 2 Jase, Rab and Pete headed off; I decided to stay with Rich and Ben but I quickly decided to leave too. Unfortunately it was midway back to the guest house that I realised Rich had the key and my phone was dead, no matter I just went for a short walk and then sat against a wall for a while - it was quite warm out. We'll certainly be using Maes y mor again.

Sunday, we all woke up quite late and after paying for the rooms and having breakfast we managed to get into the vans about 12ish. After that was the long old climb that goes on and on! We did the techy climb followed by descending the slab which was ace. After that we headed back to the conti loop and rode it backward to get back to nant. We chose to skip hippity hop in favour of doing white fridge whilst there was still light. It was a fantastic ride although majorly cold. I also made the choice of going through every water obstacle - that didn't make it any warmer and several times I was in upto my axles!

After that was home time, 4 hours back to Aberystwyth! It was a great weekend and I'm looking forward to the Dyfi warmup for more!

entry.title: Let's talk MS
entry.summary:
No, not Microsoft; I'm talking about Multiple Sclerosis. I was diagnosed with this back in October, part of the reason for writing this is so that anyone who I tell who has no idea about it can be directed here. Another part is so that in the future I can log any relapses that I have and keep a record. So I'd best start out with what it is. At a very basic level if we think about electrical wiring then you have the core wire that carries the signal and a coating that prevents anything messing with that core wire, causing short circuits. This is kinda like nerves, you have the nerve and it has a sheath of something called Myelin. In MS something causes the immune system to attack this Myelin sheath leaving the exposed nerve open to damage. This can have (what I understand are) fairly random effects with varying levels of severity. There are also 2 types: relapsing remitting and progressive. I have the former and don't ever want the latter, for further reading the MS Trust Website has proved fairly invaluable.

Let's move onto how it's affected me. I've had a handful of relapses now although none have been what I'd call severe, none of them have altered my lifestyle. Trying to pinpoint when it started is pretty difficult but for ages I had slightly less sensation down the left hand side of my body and I also had tingling in my feet, legs and sometimes my torso when I looked down. The tingling is known as L'hermitte's sign, naturally I ignored it for ages! When I did finally go to the doctor they sent me off for MRI scans of which I had 2 in Aberystywth and 1 in Swansea. The Swansea machine is much, much nicer - the one in Aberystwyth was actually painful, the head cradle has pointy bits and I was once in it for 1.5 hours! I never followed up the one in Swansea until September when I went to a GP in Oxford and they chased it, the GP suspected MS and referred me to a specialist. I've had a few other things too, my eyesight in my right eye has gone blurry twice and I lost pretty much all skin sensation on my left leg once, each of these relapses has only lasted a week or two. I can't remember if I've had anything else. To be fair I can live with loss of sensation, it's loss of use of limbs or the like that I'd rather not ever get! Typically after a relapse the symptoms go away or at least do for the most part. Currently the only thing that I have is that my finger tips have lost some sensation and that seems to be fairly permanent.

Onto the drugs, as I've had more than 2 relapses in a year I'm eligable for disease modifying medication. These drugs are meant to reduce the number of relapses. The consultant told me that typically people have 3 relapses a year and with the drugs that tend to drop to 2, given that the effect of a relapse seems pretty random reducing them seems like a good idea to me. The drug that I've chosen is something called Betaferon of the Beta Interferon family. I'm not going to pretend that I have a clue about what it does or that I really made an informed decision about which drug to use. My choice was made on what I thought fitted my lifestyle/impacted upon it the least which is what I was told to make the decision on. Each drug has a nice list of side effects but the most common for this one appears to be flu like symptoms for the first 3 months or so. My appointment to find out how to use the drugs and my first injection is a week on Tuesday so I guess that Wednesday will be fairly revealing.

Thus far the nurses and doctors of John Radcliffe Hospital and DK Earley and Partners have been fantastic and explained everything really well to me. No doubt I'll be seeing plenty more of them.

So all that is certain is that the future is rather uncertain but, hell, whose isn't?! I'll continue to live my life as I always have and deal with any obstacles as they happen, much like everyone else does...
