entry.title: Coed-y-brenin Enduro 2012
entry.summary:
So, Friday I hitched a lift up to Coedy with Jimbo and Richard (who I hadn't met before) to meet up with Ben, Jimbo and Richard were staying in a nearby B&B but I opted for the cheaper option of Bens van. The drive up went well and traffic was good, once in Dolgellau Ben and I grabbed some food at a pub which was also pretty good! We headed back to the campsite and it was pretty dead so we just grabbed a couple of beers before heading to sleep. The night in Bens van was pretty cold but all things equal was fairly comfortable. By the time we got up cars were slowly arriving and by 10 the place was packed. Race plates fitted, breakfast eaten, bikes put together, riding time!

Everyone gathered for the race briefing and there was about 250 of us in total. Briefing over and off we went, Ben and I had decided to stick together and take it easy, Jimbo went roaring off ahead of us. We rode with some of the abermtb guys for quite a while during various sections too. The climbs were often long but just fire roads so just grinding up wasn't so bad, although by the end they were making me feel pain somewhat.

The good - some of the off piste descents were truely cracking, steep and due to it being wet very muddy. Really, really good fun those were, some flowly singletrack too. Everyone on the day were really nice and most people pulled over to let us pass on the descents. We ended up bumping into 3 guys from Birmingham quite a bit and they were an excellent laugh, could hear them a mile off! Unfortunately I did go OTB in front of them which was a tad embarrassing but nothing was hurt bar my pride. Some of the actual trail centre descents were also pretty good fun, what i believe is the final descent on the trail centre of the road was a hoot. Also, the food station was cracking!

The bad - To be fair at the time I thought that there was a lot of bad but realistically not that much sticks in my mind. There was a section that was a long old climb through fields and really bad muddy wooded bits. In all fairness to the course designers the rain didn't help and from what I've heard they couldn't link everything up without it. We had a brief chat with some marshalls and they said that not even the top guys managed to ride the wet grass bits. Other than that bit not a lot sticks in my mind as being bad except...

The ugly - After the final descent of the trail centre side of the road we crossed over to the Tarw side. This I did not enjoy, by this point I was pretty tired and just wanted to finish, what actually happened was another 15km or so of riding round the Tarw trail with a few big old fireroad climbs. The descents were roughy and rocky so were hard work as I was already pretty knackered. Had I been less tired I think that the descents would have actually been cracking. Also worth going in the ugly is that Ben had 4 punctures, he used up not only all his spare tubes but mine too!

Overall, I really do not know if I'll do it again, at the time had you asked me then I most certainly would have said no but I'm not sure. I think that next year I really need to work on my fitness as that would go a long way to helping enjoy it. It was much, much harder than the Dyfi enduro which I had not expected. End of the day though it was a day riding bikes in Wales so can't be that bad!

Position - 254th out of 269 overall, 134th out of 140 in category, Duration 7hr 46min 29sec. All you can do is laugh!

http://runkeeper.com/user/chvck/activity/121776226

Why we're so happy here and everyone else is not, I have no idea!

Finally, the end.

entry.title: The Alps
entry.summary:
Destination: Morzine. This trip had been in the pipeline for a fair few months and I was looking forward to it. We were due to fly out on Saturday 4th. George had kindly agreed to drive us to and from Heathrow on the Saturday in his parents' estate. Ben and Taylor arrived at my place on the Friday night to get bikes sorted and generally get ready for packing in the morning and getting to the airport. About 10 minutes after arriving Ben realised that he'd forgotten his passport... he wasn't best pleased about that. He went home to get it (2 hours to get here and then straight back again!) and decided to come back in the morning after sleeping.

Saturday morning, all kit ready to go and car packing time. So, 3 bikes in bike bags don't fit in a Mondeo estate. Problem. In the end we managed to squeeze everything in by taking Taylors bike out of the bag and playing quite a bit of bike tetris.

T'was a bit of a squeeze...

Once all that faff was done and dusted we actually managed to get to the airport with plently of time to spare. We checked in etc... and didn't get charged for the bikes which was nice! A pint and something to eat later and it was boarding time. We flew with Swiss air and during the flight we got given ice cream and Swiss chocolate, pretty good. Other than the ice cream and chocolate the flight was a flight. We collected baggage and did all that jazz before meeting up with the other three guys we were there with - Jase, Rab and NC. I hadn't met these guys before and they were sound. Transfer from Geneva to Morzine and we arrived at the chalet.

In the air

Sorting everything out at the chalet

The chalet

At this point I feel that I should mention that we were catered for. The chalet was massive, big enough to hold 26 (I think it was). Upon arriving we met Paul, the chalet manager/chef and he told us that it was just us and 3 other guys for the whole week. Oh, there was also a hot tub, that's worth a mention. We unpacked all our stuff and sat down for our first meal of the week. Well, the food was excellent and stayed that way for the duration of our stay. First night there so we went out for a few in Morzine, it was fairly quiet but we had a pretty good night.

Sunday, rain, lots of. Slightly hungover and not a good forecast for the day we decided to hold off on starting the riding for a day, no point in buying a lift pass to find the lifts shut for most of the day due to storms. Instead we wandered into town for a bite to eat and to get our bearings. After we'd eaten we had a bit of a wander round and during this time some form of street procession started up, it was really pretty random. It was mostly vans and large vehicles covered in trees and tarps etc... To mind I remember there being 101 dalmations - kids on skates being caught by a bloke who put them into the back of a van. Loads of classic rally cars and a dragon. Yes, a dragon. It was a tractor with a grab on the front that was covered in a tarp (no, the driver could not see where he was going), the grab meant that they could move the dragons head which was actually pretty cool! Anyway, that excitement over we bought some beers and headed back to the chalet where we just chilled out for the rest of the day.

Monday, bikes. We rolled out of the chalet about mid morning and decided to hit up the Pleney. We bought our lift passes (93 euros for 6 consecutive days I think) and made our way up to the top via chair lift. Chair lifts are utterly awesome. First run in we decided to take the blue run just to ease us in. It was fairly bumpy, pretty steep in places and fairly slick. I think that it's safe to say that we were all a little bit worried about how hard other tracks would be if this was a blue. It wasn't a blue, it was a black. Taylor had somehow managed to take us down the wrong one, oh well - at least we felt better that it was black!

The crew for the week, except Ben

Second time lucky

Next up we did the blue. This was mostly double tracky fireroad type stuff and was seriously bumpy, braking bumps were a recurring theme for the week and were not fun on my hardtail. It was a pretty boring track really. Next up we tried the other black track, this was a good'un! It had steep bits and was twisty and drops and was fun! It wasn't full of braking bumps as bad as other tracks for some reason and was one of my favourites of the entire trip, certainly my favourite in the Les Gets & Morzine areas! It also had a short section called 10% which was just a steep run into a berm or 2, I really thought that I was going to lose a wheel in the braking bumps going down that.

At this point we stopped for some food and a drink and decided to head over to Les Gets. We rode the linking section from Morzine and popped out at the top of the bottom section of the Les Gets red line main run. It started out with a few jumps and then worked it's way down through loads of berms. Pretty fun. By this point it'd started raining again and the chair lift up to the top was not fun, wet and windy. We pretty swiftly headed on down the main line. It was jumpy, bermy and wide. Oh, and FULL of braking bumps. Not just a few around corners and what not but a constant stream of small bumps with a few big ones thrown in for good measure. It was really, really hard work on the hardtail, gave me a pounding and was difficult to keep up any speed. None-the-less a pretty fun track that would be a great laugh without the braking bumps! At the bottom of this we were all utterly plastered in mud, most of us had given up with goggles due to them instantly getting covered. A couple of the guys were only wearing XC jerseys on their upper half and were getting pretty cold so we decided to call it a day and ride back along the road to Morzine.

No shortage of mud

Somehow Ben and I got left for dead going down the road (suspect super tacky tyres had something to do with it) and we decided to throw in an extra run of the fun black line down Pleney. I really did like that track! After that it was home for showers, hot tub, food and chilling out. Rab, Jase and NC also managed to spend 3 hours in the hot tub!

Proper way to wind down!

Tuesday, dry! Tuesday we decided to head straight over to Les Gets and explore the area a bit more. We got there and did the main line to warm up, it had dried up a bit and was even bumpier than I remember, didn't hugely enjoy it. After that run we headed over to the jump park and did a couple of runs over there, they were mostly just berm after berm and ridiculously bumpy, not ideal for me! A bite to eat and we headed back to the main Les Gets lift to check out the canyon run. At this point Ben and I also swapped bikes. Wow, the top of the main line was suddenly a lot more fun! DH bike just took out most of the buzz of the smaller bumps, it was great. We did the top and headed over to the canyon. This trail was also great, it was rooty, steep in bits, small drops and fairly tight (as the name suggests). There was another track that ran down with the canyon but jumped across it back and forth, we gave that one a miss! After that track we decided to try out the other side of Les Gets, this only really had 1 track. It was a good track that was pretty easy but fast and steep. Oh, and full of braking bumps (getting the theme yet?) but it was still good even though my arms did die at the bottom each time. We did that a couple of times before calling it day.

Paul had said that most of the guides and chalet guys etc... had Wednesdays off so we decided to head into town for a few drinks again. It was even quieter than Saturday! We had a few drinks and then Rab, Jase and NC headed back, I decided to stay with Ben and Taylor but to switch to energy drinks as I didn't fancy getting battered. We had a couple of drinks before deciding to try Opera which seemed to be the main club, not only was that utterly, utterly dead but also 10 euros for a shot or bottle of beer. We gave up without having a drink there and headed home!

Wednesday, rest. Taylor, Ben and I decided to have a day off and just chill out. Not much happened. The other guys went up Super Morzine and said that sections were some of the steepest stuff that theyve ever ridden, that made it high on my agenda.

Thursday, disaster. We decided to head up the Super Morzine and then explore over the other side of the mountain and maybe head to Chatel. The top of Super Morzine is a separate chair lift so you can lap it, we decided that we'd do a single lap of it before heading further afield. One lap done and I realised that my forks had broken, I had no travel and they were just clunking up and down. That was that for me, I headed down on the road and headed for the Scott shop which Paul had recommended to us. As chance would have it Paul was getting ready to go for a ride there and gave me the name of a mechanic at a different shop to go and have a chat to. Unfortunately he wasn't there so I headed to the chalet and set about fixing the forks. After a lot of swearing and effort I got the air unit apart (most stupid, stupid system ever). It all looked OK until I realised that the positive air piston wasn't attached to the rod, it'd blown off - blowing a circlip off in the process. Simple to fix at least, I put it all back together and too kthe chance to remove the spacer and make them 160mm again. That took me the best part of the day so I just chilled out until the others returned. Had a bit of a chat about where they'd been and it sounded pretty ace.

Friday, disaster again. Exact same as Thursay, top of Super Morzine I lost all travel. Not happy. Headed into town and headed straight for the shop Paul had suggested to talk to the mechanic, as luck would have it he was in. His opinion was that the rod was damaged (I was pretty sure it wasn't) or that the circlip was on upside down. Wait, what? Yeah, so turns out that circlips aren't all symmetrical and that they have a rounded and a flat edge, flat edge takes the load. Learn something new every day! Back to the chalet and repaired forks again, by the time I'd finished it was getting on and I'd lost confidence in the fork so I just chilled out again with the aim of getting a hire bike for Saturday. I asked Paul where to hire one from and he told me to use his bike (Iron Horse DH bike). Brilliant! What a legend! The other guys had been over the same as Thursday and had a pretty good time.

Saturday, aaaaace! We headed straight over to Les Linderettes which the guys had said was good. It really was. Having a downhill bike made so much difference, the braking bumps were still noticeable but the ability to just plough through them at speed and not lose all control and speed really made the difference. We mostly rode 2 tracks over there, one of which was the old French national - this was one of my favourite tracks - it was fast with a bit of tech thrown in. We also headed up the Marmotte on the chair lift, that was a long old lift. Once up there we had a choice of black or red descents, the black seemed to take us down the wrong side of the mountain so we went for the red. It wasn't amazing, it started out really pedally and then got a bit more fun although quite wide. Ideal for a hardtail ironically. We spent a good portion of the day riding Les Linderettes before riding back to Morzine via a goat village (I kid ye not) and a nice lake to swim in for a bit.

Top of the Marmotte

Lake!

Sunday, home :(. Nuff said.

Overall, it was a great holiday, big thanks to Paul for that. Next time I won't be taking a hardtail, it's just not the tool for the job out there for this sort of riding. Next time I think that we're thinking of going somewhere more off the beaten track too and making more of a road trip out of it, should be ace! Now, to find a full sus frame....

entry.title: Final Ride Out
entry.summary:
The move is almost upon us and I decided that I wanted one last long ride. So I decided that for old times sake a ride out was in order, no real plan - just ride up to nant and do whatever. Ben H asked if he could tag along too, he didn't quite realise that i was going for a bit of a long one at the time though! Anyway, Sunday morning rolled round and Ben arrive around 10.30, we waited for the episode of True Blood (yeah, I know) I was watching to finish and then headed out, the weather was good - cloudy but not wet and it was a nice temperature too. I had organised my thoughts into which way to get up to Nant so we headed out on the A44 until the road that leads off and climbs up to the Waunfawr - Capel Dewi road. We went along that and continued to Capel Dewi before heading on up to Nant through Banc-y-darren.

Once up Nant we headed down Zorro and played the no pedal game, always a fun one! Once down we had a spot of lunch before heading up the leg burner. About halfway up we came across the landslide that I'd heard about. Wow, wasn't expecting that much damage:

I'm not even sure that stream was there before and if it was then it certainly wasn't as open as it is now. Pretty incredible what water can do! Once we'd finished marvelling at the landslide we carried on up and over to Hippity Hop then Drunken Druid. At this point we turned off and went through the gate to do a rather rocky descent that I hadn't done in a while. Wow, water had taken its toll here too, some bits were more like riding trials than a descent - it was pretty wild! At this point I decided that we'd head out on Joe's Back Garden and hit an obstacle...a stream that was just a little higher than normal:

We found a place to leap over and continued out along the stream bed which actually had a stream in it and was rather rutted and rocky. Once on the road we went over to the resevoir and over the dam before going round to link back up with the Conti trail and continued along that. The puddles on the inward part from the resevoir were ridiculously high and the mx-ers have made a right mess of the banks going around them. The first descent on that part is also rather wild now and really good fun! The Bont Goch climb hasn't recovered since the last time I went up there and is still very scarred from the water with a fairly decent sized stream running down it in a massive rut! Once up the top of the climb we took the bridleway down instead of the Bont Goch descent, just for something a bit different!

We continued along the road and then followed the Conti loop back to nant. By the time we popped out up the top of Hippity Hop we were both feeling the distance in our legs and decided to do Hippity Hop and then head back home via White Fridge. At the bottom of White Fridge I decided to take my rear brake pads out to have a look at why they were making such an odd noise. Yeah, no pad left and rubbing metal on metal, that old one! Unfortunately the spring was also utterly dead and so I couldn't fit the pads back in, luckily the only downhill we had left was on the road so a front brake only would suffice. We descended down to Penrhyncoch before climbing back up to Capel Dewi along the little back road, Ben was off and pushing this point and I was feeling knackered! Neither of us fancied climbing up the Capel Dewi to Waunfawr road so we decided to return via the roundabout just out of town.

All in all a nice ride with good weather. Certainly a great ride to remember the area by with some great views. Going to miss these hills!

entry.title: Mach n Back
entry.summary:
The time for us to leave Aberystwyth is rapidly approaching. Ben and I wanted to do a 100km mtb ride before that time arises so using the Mach & back route that I did with Dave Reed and the Ystwyth gang I plotted a new route adding in some different bits to get the distance up. The basic difference was to be that we'd kick out further on the way out by going further along the Conti loop doing most of the Bont Goch descent before doubling back on the rocky descent and then doing the long slog of a climb up to Anglers. Then on the way back we'd climb up to the Bont Goch descent again but take the bridleway down and then come back to Nant along the usual Conti Loop and do a Summit loop too. Oh, we also parked in the forestry car park outside of nant so that would add a reasonable amount of distance too.

Now the days running up to this were wet to say the least. Friday saw the beginning of flooding in the area but Saturday was due to be sunny all day. The morning came round and it was wet but the rain had stopped. A quick look online showed massive flooding in the area but we decided to go out anyway and got to the forestry car park at about 10.30. It wasn't exactly nice out and getting out of the van I stepped into a stream that had never been there before! I wasn't feeling stoked at this point:

We trundled over toward Nant and got to the bottom of the Pendam climb that pops us up near the base of Hippity Hop. Wow! There was an unreal amount of water flowing down the track and the stream nearby was completely white and very rapid. Climbing up this bit of the climb there was a constant rut that went to about 3 foot deep in places - utterly, utterly crazy. The photo below shows the water streaming down the track, never seen it like that before. We thought that this was a lot of water, little did we know...

Onward we went and kicked out onto the Conti trail, as soon as we came across the first lake we noticed that it was ridiculously high with water everywhere.

At this point a Forestry Commission 4x4 came along and we had a brief chat with the guy who told us that Nant-y-moch resevoir had received 10 inches of water the previous day and that they were struggling to stop the dam from overflowing! The epicness of this ride was rising pretty rapidly! Onward we went until we hit the first bit of a river crossing which has a bridge. The path to the bridge itself was flooded and we had to find a bit of an alternate line to it but the path away from the bridge was flooded in all directions and we had to jump the fence and trudge through a bit of shallow bog to get back to the path. Unreal!

We decided that we'd continue on the route that I had planned which cut off the Conti trail at this point onto a bit of track that I'd done before with the Ystwyth guys, a fair amount of this track was now a stream but rideable! We continued on and did the ridiculous grass descent down to the resevoir where the Conti loop joins. Ben managed to hit a tuft of grass and have a bit of a comical off too. Back on the Conti trail we rode the bit that leads to the resevoir backward and we'd then cross another stream and cut down to where one of the Conti trails descends to from the resevoir (we'd do this descent later). First major issue of the day! As we approached the stream we could see a group of motocrossers stood about and as we passed them one was walking back toward us. His sole comment was "Good luck with that", I didn't think much of it and figured that we'd find a way across. Uh, no. The stream was way, way too high to get across and despite back tracking down the river for a while we couldn't find anywhere to cross. We bikehiked back across directly to the trail that we'd just come along and rode back along it and started following the Conti trail the correct way again.

I was expecting the puddles in this section to be quite bad but they looked deep enough that we decided to skirt around the sides of all of them. We hit the descent and it was pretty wild, streams running down it everywhere and big rocks all over the place. Just as we got to toward the end we overtook 2 of the motocrossers we'd seen earlier, putting us down a really crap line with a lot of water running down it and some big, sketchy looking rocks. No matter we made it down fine. At this point we had to wait aaaages for the motocrossers to get up the start of the climb to the Bont Goch descent, they were taking forever. In the end we just gave up and passed them, not often you overtake crossers going uphill!

The Bont Goch descent itself was really, really hard work with a stream running down it and massive rocks all over the place. Most of the previous lines that i knew were totally gone. The rocky descent just off the Bont Goch descent was just as bad with line choice being pretty key to not either going down a hole or smacking into a big rock. We got down unscathed and started on the long climb up to Anglers Retreat, the start of this road was underwater too (below) but the actual fireroad was fine and there was even a bit of sun starting to show! At the top of this climb there's usually a stream crossing followed by a short, sharp technical climb. We had a brief discussion and decided that the stream crossing would likely be uncrossable so skirted around that section on the road...into the wind which was really starting to pick up now! We continued on up the fireroad to the start of the next descent which actually started off fairly dry but I felt that sudden feeling that the rear of the bike felt dead. Rear tyre totally flat. Quick swapping of tubes and we were off again, following the standard set so far this descent was also soaking but most of the lines had stayed intact.

Next up was the bit that links Anglers to the Mach 3, I'd only done this once before but we picked it up easily enough and skirted around a couple of puddles before hitting a stream crossing. This was completely and utterly unpassable. It was very deep and looked really fast. Quick look at the OS map and we decided to head back up to the start of the previous descent and pick up a fireroad there. Once we got to the point that marks the start of that previous descent we stopped for a bit of lunch and decided that we'd head back to Nant as we didn't know if we'd actually be able to get to Mach and it was getting to be fairly late already. The usual way back has a deep crossing that we decided wouldn't be a good idea so we picked up the road and headed back that way before picking up the Conti loop backward again and riding the same bit of trail for the third time! What really struck us at this point was that the water level had gone down loads. We actually make it across the afore-mentioned bridge with no problems and even the lake had gone down a fair bit.

Once back at Nant we picked up the Summit loop and did Hippity Hop, Drunken Druid and High as a Kite before a brief break at the visitors centre. We left off from there and headed up to the Italian Job and saw a sign stating that the Summit trail was closed due to a landslide, this we later learnt was on the leg burner, a section had collapsed. We had no intentions of going down toward the bottom end of the trail anyway so pushed on and did Italian Job and Hippity Hop. All of the Summit trails that we did were running fine and felt good as usual. We did the really eroded climb from earlier backward which was pretty wild in bits and continued on to and did the top of White Fridge which was also ace before heading back to the van.

Ace ride that despite not getting us either Mach and back or 100km was great fun, a bit of an adventure and 60km! Thanks to Ben for the photos.

entry.title: Sebs Stag
entry.summary:
Saturday was Seb's stag do which was set to be go-karting, comedy club and a night out. I left home at around 9am bound for Ben's place and from there we continued to Coseley Go karting (via a few wrong turns because Ben knew better than the sign that said "Go Karting this way"). Yes, their website does have a video that starts playing loud music as soon as you load the home page, no I do not know who thought that was a good idea. We managed to somehow arrive bang on time and met a few new faces and saw a few old ones too. It had been a very long time since I had last seen Rob and Seb, about 2 years! We wandered in and got suited up, registered etc... and George managed to turn up mid-briefing so we were all sorted and ready to go. The karting consisted of 10 seeding laps followed by a 60 lap race. The karting was pretty good fun and I was pretty surprised how much it made my arms hurt, drifting over the small bumps in the floor really, really hurt! Unfortunately I had to pull off after about 20 laps (was in 4th at the time, out of 10) due to my back bneing in agony. It's probably worth mentioning that I had a massive crash on my mtb Friday evening...

Once I'd pulled off I stood in the spectator area and watched everyone else. There were plently of spins and crashes and quite a few diagonal flags were shown. This was the flag that signified that you were driving too recklessly and to calm it down or you'd get pulled into the pits for a "chat". About 40 laps in I saw someone get the diagonal flag and then hit someone else pretty hard mid-lap, sure enough they got the special yellow and orange checked flag and had to pull in. Probably could have already guessed who it would be and the number 2 on the front confirmed my suspicion - it was Ben. Sadly for him he was in first at the time! A few more uneventful laps and the race was over. Rob won with Seb in second place, Ben managed 6th despite having been pulled into the pits! I, obviously, came in last!

Karting over we headed into the centre of Birminham to the hotel. This took quite a while longer than planned too. Rob and George were following us in the car behind and after driving for quite some time rang through to ask if we knew where we were going because they thought that we'd passed where we wanted to turn off about 10 minutes before. At this point we had to admit that no, we didn't have a clue! But, no harm done, we turned around and headed back int he right direction, we parked up in the very busy multi-storey carpark next door to the travelodge for a pretty sum of £3 for 24 hours, can't complain about that really - pretty good! Travelodge was as expected, a travelodge. We showered, changed etc... and headed to Jimmy Spices. This place was an all you can eat buffet of a load of different cuisines. I tried quite a variety of the food on offer and really enjoyed their butter chicken. Somehow, despite taking it easy, managed to eat too much and felt pretty bloated for the next hour or so after, fairly typical.

Once we'd been fed we headed toward the Highlight comedy club via a pint or 2 in Spoons. We arrived in Highlight to find that Paul had ordered the Stag package so we had a table right at the very front of the stage, could already see the fear in Seb's eyes! We also had table service which we all cunningly managed to forget time and again. Ben bought a 4 pint pitcher for the 2 of us and that did us for the duration of the time that we were in there. I'm not going to lie, I can't remember the names of any of the comedians. Tell a lie I just remembed the compere was Rudi Lickwood. He was very good, loads of laughs and kept coming back to pick on Seb a bit and tell him the woes of married life. The other comedians were also very good including a sort of slap stick duo who had a very, very clever act. I was quite amazed at how little heckling there was, anyone who tried pretty rapidly got shot down and made to look a fool by the act that was on at that time.

After the comedy club we headed to Gatecrasher, this was the part of the night that I hadn't been looking forward to so much! Once we were in we went for a short walk to see what rooms etc... there were and wound up at a bar overlooking the main dancefloor. We were quite quickly joined by a group of very skimpily dressed girls with very odd makeup and cans strapped to their heads. They turned out to be the dancers, still no idea what the get-up was all about - very odd! Ben, Rob and I bought a round of JD and cokes each, at 12 quid a round, 1 round was enough! At about 1am everyone headed to the dancefloor so George and I decided to head back to the hotel, Gatecrasher wasn't really our scene, especially not the dancing part! Ben came back a while after us and then Rob came in later on, Rob had come back with the others and somehow Paul had managed to get his phone stolen, he was rather drunk!

In the morning we had a pretty average breakfast in the hotel but at least it was unlimited and had a coffee machine! Once we'd eaten and grabbed our stuff we all said our goodbyes and headed off. Next time I'll see Seb will be his wedding in July I suspect. All in all it was an enjoyable day, a bit pricey but I had fun and I'm pretty sure that Seb did too so job's a good'un!

entry.title: Clarach Shred
entry.summary:
Dyfi enduro was yesterday so Ben and I decided that a bit of downhilling was in order, had enough of riding uphill. We took the morning fairly easy and chilled before heading over at around lunch time. We started out by hitting the top of the main line a couple of times, neither of us really in the mood for a full push back up. It was riding fast and fun. We decided to try the new line that the freshers have built as neither of us had ridden the full thing. Fair play to them, really, really fun blast of a track. Nothing too technical but fast and jumpy. Since I had last ridden it they'd added 2 massive berms and a big jump in at the bottom. The berms are big and ace to ride, the jump on the other hand just isn't quite right. The takeoff is somewhat steep and short and the landing is tiny and too close! Every time we hit it we were overshooting the landing to uphill which isn't all that great on a hardtail I can tell you! But all in all they've done a good job, there are a couple of tricky bits that are slippery and off camber, I also managed to have a bit of a stack trying to ride out a really cheeky bit of a line!

We also hit up the top of the wall ride track and spent ages working down a couple of the tracks taking photos and generally messing about. Rad shred and great way to finish off the 3 day weekend!

entry.title: Dyfi Enduro Weekend
entry.summary:
This weekend marked the annual Dyfi Enduro event. A couple of the old abermtb group were coming back for this and it was shipping up to be a good weekend of riding. Ben was, as usual, staying with me and we arranged to meet Joe, Stu, Paul and Andy over at Capel Dewi at 11 for a bit of downhill before heading to Nant-y-arian at 2. Before setting out in the morning Ben and I had the simple, single, task of changing my brakes pads. As is always the way, this was not a simple task. The brake pads themselves took a lot of convincing to get in and even after letting some oil out of the system there was no way the rotor was going in! After much wasted time, I remembered that I had a partially worn set of contaminated pads. With a bit of convincing we got the rotor to go in with these pads fitted. However, we had cunningly managed to let air into the system so we pissed about bleeding the brake for a while till we had a fantastic lever but a rear wheel that didn't spin freely! We figured it'd do.

En-route to Capel Dewi (running late) I received a fun phone call from my Dad informing me that I'd been caught speeding when I went down to Oxford. This was shaping up to be a bit of a crap day. I couldn't get my head in the game at Capel Dewi but we hit up a few runs and I still had fun. The ride up Nant-y-arian went much better! We met up with a group of Paul's mates from Norwich in the carpark and set out. The trails were riding really nice and the climbs felt pretty good, we even snuck in secret Zorro. Such a fun descent featuring drops, singletrack, scree slopes, jumps, all in all pretty rad! First ride in a while where I came bvack totally dry too, always good!

Bright and early Sunday morning we headed for Machynlleth to park up and sign on for the event. Race plates fitted (701 here) and bikes ready to go we (Ben and I) joined the ever growing queue of riders and their bikes waiting for the starting gates to open. After a bit of a light hearted briefing the gates opened and the riders were off. After the usual stop and starting we managed to get through the gates 5-10 minutes later! Letting off 7-800 riders in one go through a small gateway is never going to be a smooth flow really! We hit the road and Ben had already managed to get ahead of me so I rode as quickly as I could along the road overtaking people where I could and being overtaken plenty too. After a few miles we hit the first offroad climb, I knew that there was no way I'd be catching Ben now so I decided to just sit back and enjoy myself and ride at my own pace to try see how quickly I could get round.

Riders waiting for the gates to open

The first climb was a long slog of a fire road but I knew that it was coming and paced myself to sit and spin away, think I even managed to overtake more than I was overtaken! Managed to have a brief chat with Dave Reed before he raced off ahead. Just before the top the climb switches back on itself in a big open corner, they usually have a band here but this time round they had a harp being played - pretty cool! At the top of the climb saw a group of cheerleaders urging us on, I was contemplating stopping for a rest but decided to push on to try get to the top of the first descent as quickly as possible to try get a clear run.

Top of Elephant I was ready to go and even though I was following someone we were going quick enough for me to hit the first kicker. Unfortunately overtaking opportunities were pretty scarse on this descent as it's rather narrow. Before even reaching the first corner we somehow found ourselves queueing up stationary. Still not sure why but eventually we started moving again, we hit the first corner and the guy in front of my looked somewhat out of his depth and managed to fall off! I quickly checked he was OK and then set off again before getting stuck behind someone else. No matter, got the end of the descent and prepared myself for climbing for quite some time. The course took us fairly directly up to the field climb where the uphill gets a bit more technical. For some reason my camelbak resevoir was refusing to let me drink anything so by this point I was getting a bit parched having not drank anything since before we started. I made it most of the way over the field before stopping and draining half of my water bottle. I then hit the really steep bit of the climb and just as i hit the top I heard a familiar voice and Andy and Stu appeared. Despite them both saying they'd be really unfit and slow they must have been going pretty quickly!

I decided to try to stick with them and following them down the descents was rather good although Andy is still somewhat reckless and made some rather interesting overtakes. The descents were all running nicely and plenty of overtaking was on the cards. I lost them at the new technical climb, I was off and pushing, as was everyone around me - not a fun climb really. The next time that I saw them was at the bottom of the World Cup descent which was, as always, utterly rad. The big dipper before it was quite entertaining with some massive puddles and plenty of people complaining, I managed to ride through the middle of the lot (well, walked one after stopping in the middle). Between big dipper and World Cup is a small climb through some trees, as I rode into the trees I could hear the iconic Star Wars music getting louder and louder. I rounded a corner and there it was, a group of people dressed up in Star Wars outfits and battling with light sabres, it was a nice distraction and helped to keep things interesting! I kept up with Andy and Stu for the start of the long, grueling climb from World Cup to the feed station but they pretty quickly shot off in the distance. After quite a long time I hit this final leg of the climb and got a bit of a kick and picked up the pace, just as I hit the top I bumped into Ben. Unfortunately his seat post clamp had exploded at the bottom of World Cup so he'd been riding the entire climb stood up - not much fun!

At the feed station we found Andy and Stu again and stocked up on food and liquids (Stu left with more food than he started with!), we ended up being there for about half an hour! During this time we bumped into a couple more faces we knew and Paul also turned up. At this point the 5 of us set off together and pretty much just rode the rest of the way together. Ben was still pedalling stood up right through to the end which kept him reigned in riding at our pace! A couple more descents and another crap climb or two saw Paul and I at the top of 3in1 having been told that this would be the end we decided we'd take it easy down and just try to stay in 1 piece. Paul flew off and I knew that there was no way we were taking it easy. We hurtled down and it was grins all round at the bottom, despite Paul taking us through a tree. At the bottom we were greated by a pretty surreal sight of a beer tent with a disco. We were given a free beer each and we couldn't be happier! We waited for Ben and then rolled down to the finish line. We finished in one minute under 5 hours, not quite as quick as I'd planned but still my best time by quite some way! It was also unfortunate that we didn't get to do the final descent but seeing that arrow pointing to the finish area not a big old climb up to the final descent was very, very welcome!

Welcome sight of the disco and beer tent!

Always a good sign!

We pedalled back down into Machynlleth to the main event area to get our Dyfi Enduro mugs and to have a bit of a sit down and a natter before heading back to Aber. An ace day of riding was topped off with a lovely meal in the Tynllidiart Arms in Capel Bangor. A really great couple of days riding with a great group of people. Here's looking forward to next year!

entry.title: Nant-y-arian evening ride
entry.summary:
For the past few xc rides I've not really been feeling the downhills. They've felt slow and forced to try make any speed on them, it's been fine over Clarach but for some reason Nant and even the Dyfi just haven't felt right. Last night that changed, I seemed to get my mojo back, the trails started to flow again and the speed was just there. I think that dropping the forks down to 140mm has played a part in that as has having a little less stress on my mind due to finding a place to live!

So, last night I met up with the ystwyth guys at our usual spot up at Nant. I'd elected to use spd's for this ride, my second offroad ride with them. I decided to use them as I know the trails well and there isn't anything that I'd be worried about riding in them at all. The first climb up the pendam climb felt pretty good, could notice the front end flicking up less with the lower travel and I got up it feeling fine, but still the slowest! We rode over the moorlands and headed to zorro. Zorro was good and felt fast, the last bit through the trees is always nice and felt a bit faster this time than my last few rides. One very noticeable thing so far into the ride was that my rear brake was squealing A LOT and not really doing much in the way of slowing me down, no matter the front was getting the job done.

Up the leg burner, I found the guys stopped at the 3/4 mark. This was the fastest time I've got up the 3/4 so far and also felt the best so far, fitness is certainly still increasing at a fairly good rate. Upto Drunken Druid which felt significantly faster than the last few times that I've ridden it and I cleared the short, sharp climb after it with no problems, spd's doing their part there I think. Midway down High as a Kite I had a bit of an incident with both ends washing out, to my amazement I clipped out without even thinking about it and got in a dab. That single dab has upped my confidence in the spd's no end!

Italian job, Hippity Hop and the top of white fridge all rode great, although I did nearly spd dump at the top of hippity hop! Back at the cars I felt good. Most enjoyable nant ride that I've had in a while, everything just felt good! At this point I decided to investigate that squeal, wheel off, pads out. Well, the picture below says more than I can in words!

entry.title: Dyfi Trail Repairs
entry.summary:
Today Dan, Gaz and I met up with the some of the locals to do some repairs to a couple of the Dyfi enduro descents. We split into 2 groups and our group went off to the top of the world cup descent to fill in a bit of a rut. The reasoning behind this was that the 2 jumps near the beginning of the trail have been built up a bit and the only real line leads straight into them! As such we filled in a bit of a massive rut to provide a nice line that leads around the jumps. Think I'll have to hit the jumps next Sunday, will be severely punished if I come up short though!

After filling in this rut we moved over to a piece of trail that I've not seen before that will be used as a climb. It's fairly, steep and loose-ish, no surprises there. About midway up we met the second group clearing back some brash and draining a massive puddle. Nothing much to do so we headed back down again. I get a feeling that I will be off and pushing for this climb, it's hard!

Next up we headed to 3in1 to cut in a bit of a new line at the top to get round the huge puddle there. Lots of raking and general moving of bits and pieces and there is now a nice line that should be quite good to ride over.

Oh, also - the weather was utterly, utterly gopping! Howling wind and tipping down for the most part. Dyfi Enduro is going to be weeeeet!

entry.title: House hunting
entry.summary:
This week I've spent Wednesday-Friday flat/house hunting for a place to rent for when we move down to Oxford. I had about 7 places lined up to go look at over the 2.5 days which increased to 9 whilst I was down there. Tuesday night I drove down to Georges where I would be staying.

Wednesday I only had 2 bookings and in the morning that got reduced to 1 by an estate agent bailing out. As George was feeling a bit crap I gave him a lift into Oxford to work which was surprisingly easier than I had suspected it would be, I also ended up taking him in and picking him up all 3 days! At midday I went to my first booking which was in Kennington which looked to be a pretty good location for getting into Oxford, upon arriving I noticed that there was also a pub pretty much the other side of the road, always a good thing! This flat was furnished and was quite nice but incredibly small and on the second floor so the road bike would be a bit of a hassle both to fit and get in. It was pretty much 2 rooms, a living area with the kitchen attached and a bedroom with en-suite. At this point it's worth mentioning that Oxford prices are bloody insane! I couldn't quite see how the price of this place was justified given the size of it, guess the price reflected the location. I managed to get from the door of the property into the centre of Oxford, including parking and getting on the p&r bus, within 15 minutes - not bad going! Naturally, being in Oxford, I had 2 burrito's.

Thursday I had 6 bookings lined up starting from 10am so I dropped George into work and headed back to Abingdon and set off to the marina. This flat was in a nice development area and wasn't a bad sized flat (ground floor) with a communal garden type area. I wasn't massively taken with it though unfortunately, the location was right at the bottom of Abingdon so not as good for Oxford or the A34 as the other properties I had lined up. I can't even remember how this place was laid out! After the viewing I followed the estate agent to my next viewing at the Vineyard flats. The next place was also a second floor flat but once again a decent size. I was taken by the kitchen which was once again joined to the living area but both areas were large and there was a nice breakfast bar as a kind of separator. I mentally noted this place as worth keeping in mind. At this point I was pretty close to George's flat so headed back, my next viewing was in the same development as his flat. I met the estate agent and it actually turned out to the be the next door down from George! Another second floor flat and this one was quite small despite the agent keep saying she was impressed with the size of it. I've forgotten what this one was like as I wasn't at all taken!

Next 2 viewings were in Botley and I noticed that they were the most expensive ones I was viewing, I didn't book these! First one was yet another second floor apartment and was OK but the kitchen was utterly tiny and had quite a lot of road noise. For the price I was majorly unimpressed and getting a bit worried that I wasn't going to find anywhere. After this viewing I had a thrilling time sat in the car for an hour waiting for my next viewing. This viewing was an actual house which I quite interested by. Upon walking to the door I could tell it was going to be fairly small, the house is on the end of a block and the door is actually round the side not on the front like the other houses! We walked in and I was instantly impressed with the layout, kitchen was a decent size and quite nice and it had a downstairs toilet too! The main living area was very nice and spacious and had wooden floors. There was a small conservatory which was nice and a private garden area which was gravel and paved with a shed, A SHED, this one I could actually bring my mtb to! Upstairs had 2 bedrooms and a bathroom which all looked alright. After a bried chat with the agent he said that a small cat wouldn't be a problem and that for the right tenatnts the landlady was prepared to knock 70 quid a month off the advertised price. Bingo, this was very much on my radar now! Quite ideal location too with good access to both A34 and Oxford.

Next I popped back to Abingdon for the last viewing of the day. This property was another house but I can't remember much about it now, I wasn't very excited by it especially the lack of white goods. I went into Oxford a bit early to pick George up as i'd arranged a chat with One Ltd just to say hi and discuss what they do etc... They were really, really nice and we had a good laugh too, hopefully I'll bump into them at hack days, geek nights etc... Friday morning I popped George into Oxford and headed back to Abingdon for my final viewing, this was a ground floor flat and was quite big. Massive joint area for the main living space and kitchen. 2 bedrooms, en-suite and a main bathroom. I decided that this would be a good backup flat as I wanted to try get the one in Botley. I rang the agent and told him that we wanted it but he told me that there was another viewing in the afternoon and that the landlady wanted to honour it, fair enough. I packed mine and George's stuff into the car and headed off. I was at the farm when Maura called me to say that the landlady wanted the weekend to consider who to take on as the other party who viewing had expressed an interest, made me nervous! In the evening I popped to the lime kiln with Ben and drank about 4 pints more than planned.

Today I woke up feeling groggy but with a text from Maura saying that we had the property! I rang the agent and got the fees paid straight away. So we're now sorted so long as we pass all the various checks that the agents run on us. All very exciting and had to try to think of a way to find some furniture and hope Maura gets a job in Oxford pretty quickly as we're going to be Ok but a bit low on spare cash otherwise. Whilst on the farm I also took a look at the array of solar panels that Dad had installed on one of the sheds, pretty cool! Here's a picture of the shed at the house we're hopefully going to be renting! I will be fortifying it A LOT.

entry.title: Dyfi Pre-ride
entry.summary:
The Dyfi Enduro is 2 weeks today so today marked the dyfi pre-ride where a group of us ride the potential route. Dan turned up at my truck at around 9am so we packed up and got on the way, planning to arrive early so that I could change wheel and make sure the brakes were aligned OK. About halfway there we stopped at some traffic lights and found the car in front was Dave, doesn't matter how early I am I never arrive before him! We arrived at the Climach-x car park and discovered that we were pretty much the last to arrive, a few faces that I recognised and a few that I didn't.

The start saw us do the first climb of the enduro, not a fun climb! It's not too steep though, just long so I sat and merrily span away until the top, at this point the weather was spitting a bit. Once up that climb we continued up to the Elephant descent, no I have no idea why it's called that. I somehow managed to be following Jon down it, he's pretty terrifying to follow at the best of times. Before even reaching the big clay left hander he managed to clip the edge of the rut and jump out of it, luckily without falling off. Cue the big left hander and Jon on the floor, luckily unharmed. About another 100 metres down the trail and I see Jon go through about 3 trees without bike, once again unharmed! At this point I thought it best to overtake and had an uneventful rest of the trail.

First descent done means time for another big ole climb, this one being largely more difficult! After climbing up to the field I knew what was in store, a fairly steep offroad climb that I'd never managed to do all in one go before let alone without dabbing. Success! For the first time ever I managed the entire thing in one go without a single dab (though it came close a couple of times!). That climb over it was time for another fun descent - Baileys.

Baileys is a steep, loose, exposed, rocky descent that's fast and fun! It'd worn down a bit since the last time that I rode it so there were less little drops and it was smoother although no less loose! Somehow I managed to be following Jon again, about half way down I saw him go flying off to the left of the trail and stop, he looked fine so I continued on my way. The big corner at the bottom has also worn away quite badly and there was a huge rut in it, by chance I somehow wound up on the high line of it so avoided the rut. All down and accounted for it turned out that Jon had lost a water bottle, not the most water bottle friendly place the Dyfi!

We continued along for a short distance up a very short incline before hitting the next downhill, which I cannot for the life of me remember! The next climb was a fairly long, tiring fireroad slogleading us up to the trail known as The Big Dipper. This trail starts off undulating with some vicious, short rocky climbs. I didn't make it up a couple of them. There were also some fairly serious puddles, several totally englufed my pedals and feet along with them, as well as a couple where I stopped in the middle and had to get off and walk through them! Once this bit was out of the way the trail continued in normal dyfi fashion, rocky n steep!

For once we didn't have to ride uphill post-descent as we rode straight into the World Cup descent, a fantastic bit of trail. Starting out fast and fairly flowy with massive ruts all over the place and a handul of jumps spotted about the place the trail transforms into very, very steep bedrock. Words can't quite describe how fun this descent is and it's all over far too fast. Pete got a flat midway down so we stopped for a breather whilst we waited for him to come down. The end of this descent also marks the start of a very long slog which is fairly steep in places. After a brief break we started out on said climb. At the top of this climb is where the feed station is usually situated so we stopped for a break and some food where the feed station would be.

Onward and steep and rocky the order of the day once again! Midway down the top of this descent I got caught between 2 lines and a moment of indecision of whether to hold the high line or drop into a rut saw me on the floor. Unscathed I let through the guys behind me and continued, just so happened that Dan had also stopped about 5 metres away from me. Within 10 metres I saw Dan get completely sideways as he hit a muddy off camber section of a rut, unfornately by this point I was already committed to his line! Luckily we both rode it out and stopped at the next fireroad for a quick relieved laugh before continuing on downhill with no more issues. At the bottom we discovered that Jon had once again lost a bottle and was hiking back off up the trail to find it. Once we had regrouped it was back off uphill again.

A fairly short climb saw us at the top of the next descent, this one I usually have a moment or two on! This is a (obviously) fairly steep trail that is covered in water and bedrock, Dan set off and I decided to follow him, for some reason he decided to choose a line that was pretty much in a stream and I decided to follow him. We reached the bottom with no issues and I knew what was coming. This was the only climb of the day where I had to get off and walk, a quite steep, rocky, singletrack climb. I wasn't alone in my pushing efforts, a few of us decided that it was the best plan of action. After a while this trail started to point back downhill, a downhill that's (you guessed it) steep and rocky but also full of whoops, great fun! Once again got down to the bottom with no problems and prepared myself for the next climb.

By this point my legs were starting to ache but I knew that the climb took us to the top of 3 in 1, a descent not far from the cars. After slogging away for a while I reached the top, most of the group was already there! A brief discussion about the next course of action decided that everyone would go down 3 in 1 and then split into 2 groups - 1 going back to the cars and the other climbing up to the Dyfi final descent. At this point I was starting to think that heading back would be nice. We coninuted onto the 3 in 1 going around a massive puddle with mud all over everywhere. 3 in 1 is very muddy as well as being steep, rocky and flowy and great fun and fast. I had a couple of moments as I wasn't following anyone so could tear along at my own speed, I caught up to Dan near the bottom where the little beer tent will be.

Everyone down the group split into 2, I knew that Dan would want to continue and I wasn't feeling so bad now, I decided that I could manage another climb. We said bye to the guys going home and cracked on, I had a good pace going on until the climb got a bit steeper and I started to really feel it in my legs, luckily Dave pulled alongside me so we had a chat which helped to forget about my legs. At the top of the worst bit Dave stopped to wait for the others and make sure that they didn't go the wrong way so I continued on not really knowing where to go. Just as I thought that I must have taken a wrong turning I saw 3 figures on the fireroad ahead a bit and descended down to them.

The Dyfi final descent, I'd only done this trail once previously and could only really remember 1 big bed-rocky corner. Dan went off and I followed, he stopped within about 20 metres shouting something about lock out so I passed him and razzed down a very fun bit of track before hitting 'that' corner. I couldn't really see what line to take so just hit the rock and slid on down into the rut at the bottom, no problems! After this it was very fast and a bit pedally, getting a bit drifty in a big right hander it was ace fun. Unforntunately we then came across a digger taking up the entire track and loads of brash all over the place. A brief walk to get round all that and the trail finished off with a fast, muddy section.

Once everyone was down it was grins all round and we set off along the road back to the carpark. Getting back upto said car park is a steep climb. I was determined to do it and for the first time ever I got cramp in my leg! None-the-less I managed to ride up the climb and was pretty happy. We stopped for a brief chat and said our goodbyes and set off home. Ace ride!

This ride was really, really excellent with a great group of people. It reminded me that the Dyfi descents are a hoot and can be pretty dangerous if you don't keep your mind in the game. This also marked my first ride post reducing the travel in the lyriks. I could certainly tell the difference on the climbs, I rarely had issues with the front lifting and I don't think that I noticed any difference on the descents. A mixture of the lower travel and being much fitter than previously meant that I cleaned climbs that i haven't before and didn't have to push up any fireroads.

Bring on the Dyfi Enduro!

entry.title: Lyriks - travel reduction
entry.summary:
It recently occured to me that it might make my life a bit easier on xc rides if I was to drop the travel on the Lyriks (solo air) a tad - giving me a lower front end for the steep stuff. The first step here was to consider the options available, two options presented themselves to me. 1 - convert to coil uTurn, 2 - use Rock Shox all travel spacers. The second step was to decide what travel I wanted.

Option 1 was by far the more preferable here, uTurn allows for on the fly adjustment meaning that I could easily wind the travel down when I wanted to and wind it back out for when I go to the alps. This also means that I could play with different amounts of travel until I got a length that I felt ideal. The major downside to this option is the price. If the parts are sourced new then a coil is £55, top out spring is £22, uTurn adjuster is £25 and a sleeve for the coil (precent scratching the insides of the stanchions) is £7. This puts the price of a conversion to over £100, quite a lot more than I was willing to pay, coil can be sourced second hand but the rest is quite tricky to source unless buying new.

In the end I opted for option 2 - all travel spacers. After getting in touch with tftuned to make sure that these would work with my '08 Lyriks (they're labelled for models 2010 onward) I ordered a set for £12, if I was to do this again I'd just buy a hand ful of nylon washers. Much cheaper and does the same job. These spacers are fitted inside of the air cartridge.

So forks in bits I started the job of taking the air cart apart. This is not a fun job, between the two ends of the circlip that holds the main body in the stanchion is a little tab. The first step is to push down on the base plate and turn it to move this tab out of the way. It rapidly became apparent that the circlip turns with the base plate, cue much swearing and pissing about. Eventually I got the circlip off and was presented with a totally different set of internals to the ones shown in the guide I was following (2010 manual).

The major difference here is that the guide shows a negative air piston, in the 08 model this piston is not present. Instead there is a little gromit that seals onto the base plate to perform the same (or similar) job. This immediately made me question where I was supposed to place the spacer(s). After a bit of searching I located the 2008 manual which showed me that I need to put the spacer above the bumper for the top piston.

Job done I put the forks back together (spending ages pissing about with that circlip again) and took the chance to refresh all the oil and lube any seals. It's really quite a simple process to change the travel and I now have fully working, fantastic feeling 140mm Lyriks!

entry.title: Myherin - at last
entry.summary:
Finally made it over to Myherin with the Ystwyth guys, well just Dave Reed. It's pretty much everything that Dave told me that it would be but it still didn't fail to surprise me with just how steep parts are. We started out with a bit of a climb on a fireroad until reaching a descent that instantly screamed Dyfi at me. Steep & rocky with woops to pump, very much like many of the Dyfi descents and formed in the same way by 4x4s and moto bikes.

A bit more riding through some steep, muddy stuff that saw me pushing and we came to what Dave described as the fireroad from hell, it started out fairly steep and then continued to increase in steepness to the point that I couldn't ride it. Sat down the front just lifted and stood up the rear just span, at one point I found myself pointing back down the hill - that signalled time to get off and push. At the top of this climb we were on top of the hill with the wind turbines, the largest in Wales apparently, we counted 38 but I'm sure that there were more.

After pootling along the top for a bit we came to the descent that we'd come out for. Dave had told me that this would be steep but that didn't quite prepare me for just how steep and loose it was! I didn't dare to let off the brakes for fear that I wouldn't stop if I did. We both got down with no casualties although I did have a bit of moment having decided to let off the brakes down some bedrock, I very quickly found the bike going sideways.

Having reached the bottom of this we continued going down on some quite mellow singletrack, somehow this section saw the only off of the evening. Dave hit a rock and went OTB, he got up fine but we quickly noticed that his brake lever had popped out of the reservoir leaving him with no front brake. One more quick descent and a fair bit of climbing and we were back at the cars.

All in all a great ride and we barely even needed our lights, only using them for the very end of the ride. The way that I would define the area is as an intense Dyfi forest. Much like the Dyfi you're either going up or down and everything is steep, Myherin is just steeper and more brutal!
